TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very great pleasure and honour to be able to participate in this debate because the Australia Remembers 1945-1995 year was a great achievement for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca). Comments made by many speakers on both sides of the chamber have drawn attention to the manner in which he initiated this program and saw it through to fruition, for which he certainly deserves the commendation of the House.

PARA.TAB: It is also an event which has been of considerable significance to literally millions of Australians of all generations. More significantly than that, it is an event which helped to cement the relationship between those generations and, further than that, to give Australians who perhaps were not even born during those years—that is probably the majority of the population now—as well as millions of Australians who lived overseas and who have subsequent to the war chosen this country as their home a greater understanding of the historic process through which all Australians lived and survived during the years 1939 to 1945.

For millions of Australians in a much smaller nation, in numerical terms, it was a cathartic experience. In those years I was very young—I was only two years old in 1942—but I was one of those who was evacuated from Asia before the Japanese onslaught following the fall of Singapore. I think I remember arriving in Sydney at the time of the Japanese attack on Sydney Harbour. My mother and I were evacuees and nobody really wanted to know us very much. We had to find the best deal we could for accommodation in the eastern suburbs. The place was literally empty. I remember that distinctly. Whole blocks of flats were empty. People had all run away because of the Japanese shells that were flying over them.

We were there for the second attack. I remember hiding in the corridor with the shells going literally over the roof. Young people in today's Australia perhaps do not appreciate that this nation, in every sense of the term, was under very great threat in those years. Our cities, such as Townsville, Mackay and northern Queensland, and certainly Darwin, Derby and Broome, were under constant attack from Japanese aircraft during that period.

In deference to my mother, who brought me out—the ship we travelled on was subsequently torpedoed on the next trip with the loss of all hands—one understands, I think, the horror that people with young children faced during those years. Women left their husbands in the war zone. My father had to remain back because he was in Lord Mountbatten's SEAC command in South-East Asia. People did not know if they were going to see their husbands or wives again. That applied in Australia as it applied throughout the world.

The Australia Remembers program, which we are now concluding, gave everybody who participated in any way during those years, whether it was overseas or on the domestic war front, the opportunity to remember and say thank you to those people who made that supreme sacrifice during those years to save their country.

Bradfield, which was a community within the local government area of Ku-ring-gai, had a very proud history in relation to the Second World War because virtually all Air Force personnel trained in Australia went through the Bradfield camp. That camp is no longer there—CSIRO have most of the land—but down by the banks of the Lane Cove River to this day, especially after bushfires go through, you can still see the remnants of the open cut trenches and so forth that were dug as part of the training program for those aircraftsmen, and in fact all ranks, that went through at that particular time.

We had other facilities in the area. We had a prison camp for the Italians near St Ives. We had the St Ives showground which, in the early period of the war, were the headquarters of a whole battalion before it was sent overseas. So in a geographic sense there are a whole series of places still in that area which are significant to the war effort. The Bradfield camp in particular is of the greatest significance to the history of the RAAF in Australia. Therefore, on the 75th anniversary of the establishment of the Royal Australian Air Force next year we will be establishing an appropriate monument to mark that occasion.

As did most other members of the House in their electorates, I established an Australia Remembers Committee in Bradfield. It is most essential that I note in particular the outstanding contribution made towards the program by the members of that committee. I refer specifically to Mrs Alice Penman OAM; Margaret Wyatt, librarian of the Ku-ring-gai Council; Flight Lieutenant Stuart Doyle; Commodore Bryan Wilson; Flight Lieutenant Ron Barber, who is president of the Roseville RSL; Ron Sinclair, who did so much for our entertainment program; former mayor Peter Derwent; Lieutenant Colonel Owen O'Brien; and Mrs Sonya Gatfield and Mrs Leonie Newson.

We did a number of interesting things. In terms of the schools program, for example, I draw particular attention to the work of the students, the senior students and their teachers of Killara High School, Ravenswood School for Girls, Masada College and the Brigidine College in St Ives, whose students worked so well with the veterans and with other civilian workers during the war in the oral history project which was coordinated by Margaret Wyatt through the Ku-ring-gai library. We now have a sound record, which will ultimately become a written record, of a whole range of people who served both on the home front and overseas but who have been long-time residents of the community. In the context of the schools program, I draw special attention to the work of Tom Peate, who established an essay competition for local schools through the support and good offices of the West Lindfield Bowling Club.

From 10 to 16 July this year, we had a display of memorabilia at the St Ives shopping centre which was organised by Mrs Alice Penman. She served in Palestine from 1941 to 1943 and on her return to Australia served in Queensland. She was ably supported by Mr Pat Reilly and Ms Margaret Middleton, of the St Ives shopping centre, whose outstanding assistance I want to draw particular attention to. The display was beautifully mounted. They put on an excellent cocktail party, where we had the opportunity not only to launch the exhibition of World War II memorabilia at the St Ives shopping village but also to entertain some 200 veterans from the local community. Among those people I give particular prominence to Major H. P. Boland; Major General John Broadbent; Wing Commander Arthur Doubleday; Major General Gordon Maitland; and Major General Sharp. As you can see, Bradfield has a full complement of most senior officers of all three services. Furthermore, we had the full cooperation of the local Ku-ring-gai council, as no doubt most other members did. I want to draw particular attention to the work of Mayor Derwent and his staff throughout the year.

On Saturday 5 August we had what we regarded as our major community event. It was a concert called `Hits of the blitz', and it was held at the University of Technology in Ku-ring-gai. We had two performances and nearly a thousand people attended. The vast majority were former service men and women from the community whom we invited to attend that very excellent concert. In fact, having watched the ABC's performance on TV, I would go so far as to say that ours was immeasurably better.

I want to draw particular attention to and show my appreciation for the outstanding contribution made to that event by the Royal Australian Navy Band under the direction of Lieutenant Tony Younglove, Jillian Donaldson and Slim de-Grey, who no doubt many of you remember. He was a prisoner of war in Changi and has continued over the years to bring the humour—so far as it is humour associated with the war—to the attention of succeeding generations. Frankly, on that night he was simply magnificent. I have referred also to Dean Sinclair, but I want to add the contribution of Leslie Martin. We had the Sydney Siders Male Chorus and the Willoughby Symphony Choir. The whole excellent program was compared by the most inimitable Gordon Boyd. It was an outstanding performance which was thoroughly enjoyed by everybody. I will never forget at the end of it, as the soldiers marched down with flags of the major allies of the Second World War, the audience stood up and sung with the greatest gusto possible Land of Hope and Glory. It would put the proms in London to shame.

On Sunday, 13 August we unveiled and dedicated a remembrance clock on the Pacific Highway, Gordon. This is a tribute from the Bradfield electorate and the people of the Ku-ring-gai municipality. It commemorates the residents who gave their lives in World War II and those who served Australia in all the other ways on the home front.

The working party for that project consisted of Flight Lieutenant Stuart Doyle; Mr Rod Cook, the council deputy engineer; Ms Alison Walker, the council's landscape architect; and Mr Tim Schwager, the honorary architect. Those involved in the dedication included the mayor, Flight Lieutenant Doyle, the Reverend James Pettigrew of the Church of St John the Evangelist in Gordon, Rabbi David Rogut of the North Shore Synagogue in Lindfield, Reverend Father Harry Davis of Nazareth House, North Turramurra, and me. It is also important to note the work of Robert Newson who provided the clock—a most important contribution under the circumstances.

On Wednesday, 16 August we launched the Ku-ring-gai During War Exhibition, which was held at the local history centre of the Ku-ring-gai Municipal Council. The council's historian Margaret Wyatt did an excellent job in organising the exhibition which was based on the wartime events in Ku-ring-gai, and I am sure she would want me to thank the literally hundreds of people who made contributions with old photographs, memorabilia, uniforms, badges and so forth to make it such an outstandingly successful event.

Part of the project is the recording of the oral testimonies of many returned service men and women and people who served on the domestic front. Many of those interviews have now been recorded. They will be edited and a booklet will be published documenting all aspects of the Ku-ring-gai war scene, especially for future generations.

On Friday, 15 September, and later on 9 November, I was involved in the presentation of civilian medals and certificates of appreciation to some hundreds of returned service men and women as well as to people who served on the home front. As has been pointed out by other members, it was fantastic to see people's reactions to this. I was surprised at the number of certificates I was presenting on a posthumous basis; no doubt that was the experience of many of my colleagues.

Over 50 years people had assumed that the contribution they had made had just passed through into history. I think that generation will be forever grateful that so many years later those who had been fortunate enough to survive were given the opportunity once again to come forward and accept the support, appreciation and thanks of an entire nation whose peace and tranquillity has been to a large degree assured by the contributions that those men and women made.

I would like to thank in particular the Mayor of Ku-ring-gai, Mayor Geddes, who also participated with me in that project. Overall, it was an extremely successful year for Ku-ring-gai and the electorate of Bradfield, involving many hundreds of people. There is no doubt that many people have come out of this year as happier people because they feel that the contribution they made was worth while and has been appreciated.

The most important thing of all was the view taken by the RSL Club in Roseville which decided at an early stage that one of the most important components of this year had to be not just the maintenance of memorials or the construction of new memorials but, rather, a program that attracted the youth of Australia to, on the one hand, understand the horrors of war and, on the other, to give through the oral program and by other means the opportunity for that young generation, whose own parents for the most part were too young to service in the Second World War, an appreciation of the significance of those years so that they could pass on traditions for the future. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first duty I have to fulfil tonight is to a Mrs Valerie Popple from Temora in New South Wales—not a constituent of mine but someone who has worked particularly hard in recent months on behalf of the pig industry. I acknowledge the effort of the Popple family, particularly Valerie Popple, in that wonderful effort in collecting, on behalf of the pig industry, all those signatures from across Australia.

PARA.TAB: In the remaining time available to me, I want to talk about the electorate of Grey. I have been the sitting member for almost three years and I have been looking at some of the statistics, the history and the breakdown of my electorate. Grey is, of course, one of the 147 seats in this House of the 37th parliament. It is the third largest electorate in the country. I was looking at the electoral atlas this evening before I came into the chamber. It is a wonderful dictionary of information on all the electorates in this parliament.

The first sitting member took his place in 1903. It lists members from a combination FT/ALP/National member right through to Lloyd O'Neil, the ALP member who retired in 1993. There has been a spread of ALP, United Australia Party and Liberal Party members over the history of the seat.

As many people will know, the electorate extends from the Northern Territory border to south of the Clare Valley to the Western Australia border and through to Broken Hill. In that breadth of 895,000 square kilometres there is a population of 130,000 people, 111,000 of whom were born in Australia.

I was interested in the comments on the news this evening from the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) when he mentioned that he had attended a League of Rights meeting. Having looked through this electoral atlas, I am very aware of the diversity of this country and I am reminded of Senator Bolkus's decision to strip the Port Lincoln Mayor, Peter Davis, of his right to officiate at naturalisation ceremonies. The member for Eden-Monaro touched on that diversity in his comments about Graeme Campbell, the member for Kalgoorlie. When I look at Grey I see a part of Australia—not unlike Kalgoorlie, not unlike much of rural Australia—which is growing further apart from urban Australia in many ways. It is an issue that we will need to address and I note that the Labor Party is going through some pains over that currently.
In conclusion, it has been my great pleasure and privilege to represent the electorate of Grey over almost three years. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Electoral Act: disclosure of political donations

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise the issue this evening of funding political parties and, in particular, refer to an article in this week's Bulletin by Laurie Oakes headed, `Liberal view of the truth'. We have had a situation in the past where quite a number of creative arrangements have been adopted by the conservative parties to disguise the origins of donors.
—Catch Tim.

—Catch Tim being one of the major examples in South Australia, with $100,000 donated through a Hong Kong company. We also had the situation where the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), had an FAI funded staff member and the honourable member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), when shadow minister for industrial relations, had a consultancy with Clayton Utz, a major industrial relations law firm—and he still has that in his list of declarations.

PARA.TAB: We had the Free Enterprise Foundation—which is very effectively revealed in the article by Mr Oakes—prior to the last election contributing something like $7 million to the Liberal Party campaign funds. Under the Electoral Act as it then stood, the origin of those funds could not be disclosed. In the article, Mr Oakes shows that $25,000 of that money came from a CSR donation to the Free Enterprise Foundation, in spite of the fact that when the Australian Labor Party approached CSR for a donation, the secretary of the Labor Party received the response that it was CSR policy `not to make donations to political parties'.

So we do have a significant problem in this country. I am pleased to see that the government is in the process of amending the Electoral Act to close the loophole that allows such things as the Free Enterprise Foundation rort to continue and to ensure that donations made to a person or body with the aim of benefiting a political party are deemed to be donations to that party.

Look at what is going on in Victorian politics at the moment with the Walker-Williams-Kennett troika through the casino and the rorted tendering process; various matters associated with Hudson Conway; the grand prix and the laws associated with the grand prix; and the fact that Ronald Walker is basically the Liberal Party bagman. You have a very unhealthy integration of very major commercial activities and political party funding in Victoria.

Funding of political parties, unfortunately, seems to be a bit like the tax avoidance industry—no sooner does the government alter the legislation than people on the conservative side of the fence start looking for more loopholes to get funny money of some description, or money that they do not want to disclose the origin of, into their campaign funds. The latest means of doing this is the clandestine corporate sponsorship or funding of staff members of coalition MPs. The classic example being FAI and the honourable member for Mackellar.

I recently heard that new version of this practice is emerging—a much more sophisticated arrangement than the FAI-member for Mackellar arrangement. A company simply `tops up' the salary of a Liberal staffer with an undisclosed amount, for undisclosed reasons. I am unable to verify this information at this stage, but it has been suggested to me that there is at least one instance where this has occurred in the office of a very senior figure in the opposition.

I call on both the government and the opposition to clarify the situation on this issue. It seems that even the new amendments to the Electoral Act may not cover this situation, as the donation could be described as not benefiting a political party, but rather the individual staffer who receives the `top up' to their salary, and of course benefiting the individual company that has made the donation or the additional salary payment without disclosure.

I therefore ask: have there been any instances in this House of this occurring, where staffers have had their salaries `topped up' by private companies? Will disclosure of this practice be required under the new legislation? If not, will the government give serious consideration to requiring disclosure of such donations under the act?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a major issue of concern in my electorate, that of law and order in country towns. The safety and security of citizens has been deteriorating rapidly over the last 20 years. We now have new waves of lawlessness sweeping country areas. It even affects people who live out of town. When they drive into town to shop, they find it difficult to park anywhere with safety. They even have their cars stoned while driving down the streets. There have been incidents of women being assaulted, harassed and intimidated while shopping.

PARA.TAB: Even in previous law-abiding towns like Lake Cargelligo where you never heard of these sorts of problems, I am now getting a number of calls from people pleading for something to be done so that the problem can be nipped in the bud.

Broken Hill, a city of 24,000, has always been relatively quiet. But there have been two recent incidents of major violence in that town, both life threatening—one innocent fellow losing the sight of an eye. The citizens are holding their first protest march on this issue soon.

In Dubbo, my biggest city, the break-ins, window smashings and assaults are a nightly occurrence, and the police seem powerless to do much about it. In towns where this has been endemic for some time, such as Bourke, they are now experiencing an intense wave of violence. Despite having the highest police numbers per capita in Australia, they seem powerless to do anything.

I hold up the latest copy of the Western Herald, the Bourke paper, with the headline, `Law and Order in Bourke in disarray' and the sub-heading, `Juveniles hold the town to ransom!' I will quote a couple of paragraphs from that front page written by the editor:

Despite years of frustration and calls from local people and businesses for Police and government bodies to resolve Bourke's law and order problems. . . the situation is no better, in fact it seems worse! Never has the lack of law and order been so evident as at the present time.

Gangs of juveniles roam the streets day and night harassing shopkeepers and customers and are seen to be above the law, showing no fear of retribution for their actions. Rightly so it seems, as nothing appears to be done.
Police say there is little they can do and the situation has reached the stage where Bourke people will not accept this.

This is the state of law and order under the Carr Labor Government which took such pride in campaigning for better law and order earlier this year. Bourke has found that Labor's promises are empty, hollow words and nothing more.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning inside the paper, there is another page full of incidents that have happened since the last edition under headlines such as, `Teenager breaks into house and attacks woman'. A story headed, `Police attacked in hotel altercation' states:

PARA.TAB: Two Bourke Police Officers are recovering after being injured whilst breaking up a fight at a Bourke Hotel on Saturday night.

It is alleged that a man assaulted the Publican of the hotel when he was refused service. Police attended the scene and when the alleged offender ran from the hotel, two officers chased him, catching up with him behind Festival Supermarket. While the officers attempted to take the man into custody, a female police officer was knocked flat on her face and a male officer suffered a bite to the armpit.

SPEECH.PARA: He is in hospital at the moment having AIDS tests. There are further headlines such as, `Local woman pays for return of purse'—which was stolen from her. When she got a phone call requesting money for the return of the purse, she contacted the police who advised her to pay the money. Another article here quotes Robyn Hams, who has become sick and tired of the constant problems. She says:

PARA.TAB: One month, we will have constant problems with theft and break-ins. A little while ago, it was so bad that we were being broken into, or having something stolen, every day. It was like a horror movie, you knew it was going to happen, you just did not know when. Then, we will go for a month or so and it will be quiet. I'm quickly becoming a nervous wreck and it seems to be a small group of re-offenders who are causing the problems. Something needs to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: That is just a small sample of what is happening. Another incident concerned Terry Mackay, a businessman who has had to shut his business down in Bourke because his premises have been stoned for up to five hours at a time. I have a police report here of 40 to 60 offenders throwing missiles at his house constantly, police attending and having their vehicles smashed up and still not being able to arrest anyone, they say, because it was dark. But his premises were stoned the other day for five hours—in the middle of the day! Police attended again and still nobody was arrested.

PARA.TAB: The situation is totally out of control and something has to be done because good citizens are leaving these towns. It is a tragedy to see these towns being put through this. I urge the federal parliament as well as the state government to do something about it to restore law and order to country towns in New South Wales. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —An age pension is a right, not a handout. The pension is a return to honest, hardworking Australians for a lifetime of building our country. That is the way we say thank you to our senior citizens for a lifetime of hard work. We respect them for what they have done and we take the responsibility of providing a decent pension.

PARA.TAB: It is easy to say these words but, if we really mean them, we must back them up with concrete policies. That is why the government has a commitment to not only index pensions regularly for inflation but also increase their real value over time. This Labor government has rigidly adhered to its commitment to regularly index pensions and, in addition, has delivered on its promise to ensure that pensions are at least 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. It is important to understand that this is a principle which is not accepted by those on the other side. If the policy that applied when the other side were in government were applied now, single age pensioners would at least be $20 a week worse off and couples would be at least $34 a week worse off.

The problem we have is that the record of the opposition in government is dreadful. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), when he was Treasurer in the Fraser government, stopped the regular indexation of pensions. If Mr Howard had the opportunity to repeat this trick it would cost the average pensioner one whole week's pension per year. That would be the equivalent of a pensioner being robbed after they went to the bank and withdrew their pension on a weekly basis. During the Fraser-Howard government, pensions fell by 2 per cent in real terms because they did not make increases in line with changes to the CPI. Under this government, pensions have increased 14 per cent in real terms and have increased at a rate greater than the CPI.

I know that it is hard to live on a pension. That is why I believe it is vital that the existing commitments are maintained and the advances of the past are not lost. This will not be possible under a Liberal government. The Leader of the Opposition made it very clear on Meet the Press earlier this week that they do not have a commitment to maintaining and increasing the real value of pensions over time. In my electorate of Lilley, the Liberal candidate has blamed our national debt on the money being paid to pensioners and the unemployed. Quite clearly, she believes that to solve national debt pensions should be cut. This is an approach which is totally rejected by those on this side of the House. We have a policy of maintaining and increasing the real value of pensions. We have a record of doing that. That is not the case with the Leader of the Opposition or the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I received on my fax machine at Parliament House a letter entitled `Telstra, Iterra Main Earth Station, Bendigo: Proposed Closure'. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: The national domestic satellite telephone system is called Iterra, operated by Telstra and has its main earth station located at 38 Short St. Bendigo. This earth station is the only one of its kind in Australia and provides control for the national system and connection to the national terrestrial network through Bendigo. The system has been in existence for approximately 10 years and has been Bendigo based for the whole of that time.

The system uses analogue technology and the time has come to upgrade to digital technology. Telstra has set the wheels in motion to achieve this but the new system, called DAMAnet, will not be based in Bendigo but instead be based in Perth. There may be a secondary part of DAMAnet in Bendigo or no satellite system at all.
The current Bendigo installation is supported by 12 staff—
and possibly others—
some of whom will be expected to relocate to Perth whilst others will face redundancy.

Organisational arrangements are about to be put in place which eliminates local management and places Bendigo under the control of management in Perth. Some of the current Bendigo jobs will also be stripped of some of their functions as a step towards elimination.

This is a disgraceful action by Telstra and I bring it to the attention of staff. I will be writing to Mr Blount, the head of Telstra, and I will also be writing to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee).

TALK.START.PARA: —There must be an election in the air or something. Tonight we are insulted by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) coming in here and talking about a state issue, saying that the federal government should do something about law and order in New South Wales. I will lay London to a brick that in the past seven years the member for Parkes has not said a single word about the Fahey government slashing police numbers in New South Wales. He knows too well that the Carr government already has embarked on building up police numbers. That is the sort of hypocrisy that we are getting and we are going to get it continually until the election.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday when this House considered private members business we heard about the Pacific Highway in New South Wales. The Pacific Highway bisects my electorate, the electorate of Paterson. Today that discussion has continued. Senator Tierney has set new parameters for the role of a senator. He is not a senator representing New South Wales; he is a senator representing the Hunter—a completely new classification of a senator.

What is Senator Tierney saying about the Pacific Highway? He is saying that the black spot funding has been cut. He alludes to the fact that the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) says they are going to bring it back. I am not sure what speech he was reading of the Leader of the National Party when he claims they are going to bring it back, because I can tell the House that when the Leader of the National Party addressed the annual conference of the National Farmers Federation earlier this year he said that the coalition will not be increasing funding on rural and regional roads because they don't want to compete for the dollar; they don't want to risk increasing interest rates. You can quote verbatim virtually anything the opposition have said because they have said it. But when you cross-reference it you find out that what they said at a certain meeting in Yass conflicts with what they said at a meeting in Canberra, Sydney or Melbourne. They have said everything.

The true facts surrounding the Pacific Highway are that for five years the Greiner-Fahey regime in New South Wales spent an average of $70 million per annum. In its first year in office the Carr government will spend $108 million—an increase of some 30-odd per cent. Those are the facts. If we want to know what the Fahey government did in the first year of having road funding come to them in an untied form—everyone knows that last year was the first year of that system following an agreement between the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and Nick Greiner, when he was the Premier—we have to ask: where did the first $50 million of road funding go? Not a cent of it was spent on a road. It was all spent on City Rail in Sydney.

If the opposition want to have a debate about the Pacific Highway and road funding, let us identify what the federal responsibility is and what the state responsibility is. I can tell you that we will back our record every time because we put the money into roads where the need is. We do not play the games, the chicanery, the hypocrisy of the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to speak very briefly about two tragedies—one a domestic tragedy and one an overseas tragedy. As patron of the Toowoomba Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME) Support Group, I am disappointed at the reluctance of many at the medical and political levels to accept the plight of Australians afflicted with this debilitating condition. At this point in time, it seems to me that deeply traditional medical attitudes prevail that this is a condition of the mind rather than of the body. Having met with many in the local support group this year, and having talked to overseas medical experts from the United Kingdom and New Zealand recently, it is clear that Australia is lagging behind overseas medical and governmental acceptance and remedial health and budgetary measures to correct this debilitating condition. Once again, on behalf of local support group president, Joan Sheath, and all CFS sufferers nationwide, I make a special plea to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and to health research authorities to do something about this as a matter of urgency in the national interest.

PARA.TAB: Turning overseas, there is no doubt that the civil war in Sri Lanka is a tragedy of the highest order. Indeed, there is no humanitarian crisis within our Commonwealth of Nations of comparable magnitude. There is, therefore, a desperate need to resolve it for all Sri Lankans—Tamil and Sinhalese alike—irrespective of religion, of ethnic identity or political allegiance. It is a tragedy that the overwhelming number of victims are civilians of all views who have been brought into the military conflict by the indiscriminate use of violence. In particular, there is a need to address the displacement of about half a million persons in the country's north who are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance.

To this end, UN Secretary-General Boutros Ghali has declared an urgent need for international humanitarian assistance to meet the needs of these people—regrettably, to little tangible effect at this point. In that context, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) called on our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) several weeks ago to raise the problem of Sri Lanka during the recent CHOGM in New Zealand and to discuss with other Commonwealth members ways in which the Commonwealth could play a useful role in resolving this tragedy.

Unfortunately, not only was the matter of Sri Lanka not included in the CHOGM communique but the issue was not discussed in any formal way at that meeting. The coalition, therefore, has criticised and will continue to criticise the government's failure until we see a substantive response. To date, our Prime Minister has refused to explain why he failed to raise it.

We should all be appalled also at Senator Evans's reference in the Senate earlier this year to the concerns of the Australian Tamil community as being concerns of `a few romantically minded' Tamils in this country. Clearly, that is not so, and I feel sure that the Sinhala Cultural Foundation would have strong views also. His failure to recognise the issue and the failure of the Prime Minister to raise the issue at CHOGM represent extraordinary oversights.

Given the moral rhetoric which flowed in other directions from CHOGM, it is incomprehensible that the Sri Lankan tragedy was overlooked. The coalition supports the need for a peaceful resolution to the crisis in Sri Lanka as a matter of urgency. We believe that there should be some international involvement in the situation, despite persistent Sri Lankan government rejection of this. Australia might play a useful role both diplomatically and politically and in coordinating efforts by non-government organisations in sending relief supplies, particularly basic medicines.

However, time is running out and thousands of people are dying each day unnecessarily in this tragedy. We all should abhor atrocities and violence both by the Tamil Tigers and by Sri Lankan government forces alike. Once again, I call on the Keating government to take genuine steps to help alleviate that crisis and to return all Sri Lankans to a state of normality, of tolerance, of self-respect and peace, free of suggestions of ethnic cleansing and with all the freedoms of responsible democracy. Clearly, Sri Lanka has a long way to go to reach these goals.

We need the Prime Minister and Senator Evans to light the Commonwealth's way towards a new Sri Lanka, where the gun is no longer needed and where peoples of all ethnic and religious groupings can live in peace and mutual prosperity. Senator Evans can no longer sit on his hands in this tragedy. Tamils and Sinhalese alike demand nothing less.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House will be aware that the Northern Territory euthanasia bill is to be resubmitted to the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly due to legal anomalies. The problem that brings me to speak today is that the parties in the assembly are denying a conscience vote for members on this issue. This is disgraceful and contrary to the established Australian norm of allowing conscience votes on matters of personal status.

PARA.TAB: We have had conscience votes on divorce, abortion and matters dealing with homosexuality, and this is right and proper. People's views on these matters go to the very heart of their entire world outlook, and the right to freedom of conscience is fundamental to our culture and the life of our nation. The conscience vote is a national rule of the Australian Labor Party that I have always defended and fought for. Ideological extremists who insist on forcing support for their agendas are actually saying that they cannot rely on their arguments to win their case.

Personally, I have grave reservations with euthanasia. To deliberately take a person's life is a very serious matter. I believe life to be a God-given gift. The serious medical traumas that affect many people today are essentially a matter for the patient and the doctor. Politicians are usually unnecessary in these situations. But when legislation is before a parliament we must certainly resist any attempt to reduce our role in the life of Australia by having the exercise of our considered consciences nullified by party factions.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 November, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report that is the subject of our discussion this morning is entitled Warehouse to wharf: Efficiency of the interface between seaports and land transport: Final report. This is the result of the efforts of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, of which I am a member, more particularly for the aviation safety inquiry aspects of the committee's undertakings though I am also interested in this particular aspect of the committee's work. In particular, I would like to mention that my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite, Stewart McArthur, has undertaken a great deal of work on this committee report. The purpose of the report is to do something that has been neglected in Australia's transport infrastructure over the years, and that is to ensure that there is a proper interface, a proper link, between all aspects of transport in Australia to ensure that we remove the hurdles of inefficiency that exist today.

PARA.TAB: If anybody looks at our transport infrastructure, they should look at it in its entirety rather than in the particularity. For example, people tend to think of road transport and only of road transport, or they think of rail transport and only of rail transport, or they think of shipping and only of the waterfront. People do not look at the entire problem of moving goods from the point of production to the point of consumption or from the point of import to the point of consumption here in Australia. They do not look at the entire interface and try to establish a seamless process by which goods are transported in Australia. As a consequence we in Australia have developed over the years a disjointed transport infrastructure where the interface has not been properly developed. As a consequence of that, inefficiencies have been built into the system, which lead to higher costs, which lead to our inability to compete satisfactorily.

The philosophy behind this report, as I am sure the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), the chairman of the committee, will state more extensively in his remarks, which will follow mine, is to look at a seamless transport infrastructure in Australia removing the hurdles of inefficiency that have been developed over the years by governments that have not looked at transport as an overall industry but have looked at particular aspects of transport without linking them together.

The waterfront is one of the most obvious and concerning aspects of Australia's transport infrastructure. Nearly everything that is imported into Australia comes through our ports. A very small component of our total imports comes via air freight but 99 per cent comes through our waterfront. As a consequence, the waterfront is a key component in Australia's transport infrastructure. As the report points out, the performance of our waterfront, historically as well as currently, is not up to the standard that people would like, and therefore the need to ensure that we have a more efficient waterfront is paramount.

There are various graphs and tables in the report, one of which highlights the waterfront performance here in Australia. It points out that there were some improvements during the latter period of the waterfront reform process. This particular table is table 2 on page 29, headed `Stevedoring performance indicators: Five major ports December 1989-June 1995'.

Whilst there was an improvement in crane rates, elapsed rate and net rate, all of the figures here would indicate that that has started to tail off over recent times. That is of course reflected in anecdotal evidence, as well as more authoritative evidence from organisations such as the Bureau of Industry Economics. The bureau's report, which came down only recently, indicates very serious concern about the deteriorating performance on our Australian waterfront. That is after an improved performance towards the latter period of the waterfront reform program that concluded in October 1992. There is no doubt, I think, from the committee's report and from other anecdotal and more authoritative reports, that our waterfront is not performing nearly as well as it ought to be.

Of course, anybody who has been reading the newspapers in the last two or three weeks will be aware of the fact that we have had a major nationwide waterfront dispute. This reinforces the view that many of us have—not necessarily shared by all people in the parliament but certainly shared by a lot of people in the parliament—that the waterfront has not really changed its spots. One of the great hopes of waterfront reform would be that the culture on the waterfront would change so that we would see a more reliable waterfront, a waterfront that would be enterprise focused rather than industry focused, and a waterfront that would not see itself as the storm-troopers or the shock-troopers of industrial relations in Australia.

We would also hope that reform would mean that, whenever there was some sort of an industrial dispute going on, the waterfront would not be automatically wheeled out to go on strike as part of an overall industrial campaign that may have absolutely no relevance to the waterfront but which would be used by the ACTU as a vehicle to try to influence public opinion or government actions to change some aspect of industrial relations unrelated to the waterfront. The waterfront is used as sort of a shock treatment to achieve success for the ACTU. The recent strike has proven that the spots have not changed on the creature at the waterfront, the Maritime Union of Australia. It is still the old organisation it always was. The culture is very much the same as it always was. In my view, the recent strike on the waterfront marks the grave for waterfront reform in Australia. However, I am sure members on the opposite side will take a somewhat different view to that. I guess they have to do that because the waterfront union, the Maritime Union of Australia, is very much an integral part, an icon, of the Labor movement in Australia.

The government has had much difficulty trying to sell ANL, which any reasonable person would say is something that should have been done a long time ago. Indeed, the government did try to sell ANL in 1991, and it has been consistently trying to sell it since. The fact that the government has not been able to sell it indicates the power that the Maritime Union of Australia has over the government. That will be evident for all to see tomorrow when the government admits defeat on its attempts to sell ANL. We will then see the Maritime Union of Australia claiming a great victory over government policy and public interest. That is the waterfront aspect of it.

The report also deals with aspects of rail—for example, the National Rail Corporation, an organisation that was established by the government in 1991. The then minister, the member for Charlton, Bob Brown, initiated those changes. Of course, all of us who have an interest in transport welcomed the establishment of the National Rail Corporation and genuinely want the National Rail Corporation to succeed. Many people would say that it is not a matter of wanting National Rail to succeed; it is a matter of making it absolutely essential for Australia's transport that it does succeed. However, from evidence that the report highlights, the National Rail Corporation is not succeeding to the degree that people would like it to, and the report refers to that. Also, those of us with an interest in transport would have picked up anecdotal evidence from freight forwarders and customers of National Rail that the performance of National Rail leaves a lot to be desired, that it has not achieved a level of performance that would satisfy customers.

I had the opportunity to talk with other rail operators when I chaired a session of the World Freight Congress in Melbourne recently in which the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe) was also involved. I happened to chair the session on state rail authorities at which all of the participants were quite critical of the National Rail Corporation for not performing, for not meeting the sorts of standards that are necessary to satisfy customers today and for not ensuring that Australia has a modern, efficient, performance oriented National Rail Corporation. There is a lot of room for improvement with the National Rail Corporation.

An area in which the corporation is very successful is public relations. All credit is due to Fred Affleck for achieving a very good public relations campaign for National Rail Corporation. That campaign is probably a darn site better than its performance on the rail track but there is a need for National Rail Corporation to be improving its performance, and the report highlights that. I hope that the National Rail Corporation will recognise the need to improve its services and be more customer oriented, more performance oriented.

Many people would say it still suffers from a culture that is a leftover from the days of rail being operated by government when, if you did not like using that particular rail service, bad luck; there was only one of them. If you did not do business with that rail corporation, then you would not do business on rail. I think we need to have more private sector competition on the rail system to keep organisations like the National Rail Corporation honest. Indeed, I hope we will have that.

Another aspect of the report is port authorities. A comparison of port authority performance in Australia with port authority performance around the world would indicate that our costs and service levels do not compare with those of our trading nations. Although there has been reform in our port authorities over recent years and that reform is ongoing, we are still not competitive against those nations that we need to compete against.

People would also recognise that state governments, which are the owners of port authorities, use port authorities as a way of raising non-tax revenue. That is not healthy for the Australian economy. If we are to have an efficient waterfront, there are two sides to the coin: stevedoring and port authorities. The performance of port authorities can be just as important as the performance of the stevedoring operation at those ports. We need to spend more time focusing on that.

We need to inject a degree of competition into our ports. That is a difficult thing to achieve, given the geography of Australia, but involving the private sector more and more in the functions of port authorities to the point of moving down the path of privatisation of some of them is a way in which Australia can look forward to improved performance from our ports and to the removal of the temptation that state governments fall victim to of using port authorities as a way of raising non-tax revenue. Moving towards the private sector is one way of helping to achieve that. Port authorities are an integral part of the process and the report highlights that, as it also highlights the poor performance of our port authorities.

The other matter that the report deals with is the need to have proper road links from our ports, from our rail stations and depots, to the manufacturing and consuming areas. There are some very substandard roads servicing our major ports. For example, I do not think that the port of Botany is adequately linked by road to the areas of production in Sydney. Most of the goods coming into the port of Sydney or that go out of the port of Sydney at Port Botany are manufactured or processed in the western suburbs of Sydney. The road links from the port at Botany to the western suburbs of Sydney are not up to the standard that they ought to be. The report makes the point that a proper warehouse to wharf approach would need to include the establishment of a good road system to those ports, to our airports, to our rail depots, to ensure that we have that. I would like to congratulate the committee—its chairman and members—on a job well done.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled Warehouse to wharf targeted the efficiency of the interface between sea ports and land transport, following a report in 1992 that highlighted some of the problems in that area of our transport system. This matter is very important to my home state of Tasmania, as most of our bulk goods have to be subjected to sea passage, and it is of some consequence if significant delays mean that we cannot get them where we want them as quickly as we would like.

PARA.TAB: This inquiry revealed, as the preface says, `an appalling apathy, ignorance and inertia on the part of users of waterfront services'. The committee in 1992 found that providers of transport were largely self-interested, and talked about each other rather than to each other. The report shows that little has changed since then. Despite everybody clamouring for better services, it appears that many traders have very little knowledge of how to use the port services. Waterfront productivity is important, yet efficiency and efficient use of transport services in the waterfront is even more important to exporters, importers and Australia's international competitiveness.

There have been some minor improvements since 1992, and the committee found that coordination and communication have improved among some parties in the transport chain on the waterfront. Vehicle booking schemes have been implemented and there is a more coordinated approach in promoting electronic commerce; but that, in itself, is taking some time to get in place, and I would like to mention that matter again a little later.

There are still problems with truck queues, late deliveries of cargo, documentation, and a mishmash of working hours between warehouse and wharf operators. The latter problem means that cargoes can be left on the dock. If the goods are in any way perishable, this can cause a major disaster. If somebody from the wharf is delivering something to a warehouse but the warehouse does not open or else restricts its opening time and its hours of opening, it makes it very difficult for that person to make deliveries to fit in with their overall schedules.

A manufacturer can make a widget and that widget can be placed in a piece of machinery which is sold to a wholesaler and then to a customer. If that widget fails and the machine breaks down, not only can the original manufacturer replace the widget but they can also trace where, and on which day, the widget was made, and by whom and on which machine. That is today's world.

Such is the advantage of a total quality management tracking system. Problems can be checked and sourced, so that they are not repeated. Yet we have in Australia a freight system such that, once a package or a container leaves the company of origin, no-one seems to have any idea of where it is in the system until it actually arrives. That is where the electronic system should be able to assist us in improving our system.

Moving away from the report, not very long ago I had a function in Canberra for which I decided to ship up some Tasmanian wine, which is always a pleasant thing to do. The company duly sent off the consignment to me a couple of weeks before the date of the function. The day before the function the consignment had not arrived. I asked my staff to check on the whereabouts of the consignment, but the company could not find out where the assignment had gone. The company could not say whether the consignment was on the wharf in Melbourne, whether it had left Tasmania or whether it was on a train waiting to come to Canberra. No-one knew. I was quite surprised that, within the system today—and given the work I have done on this committee—we could not find out where in the chain something had gone.

A fine state of affairs exists when a customer is waiting for a particular product for a particular day and no-one can tell the customer when, where or if it will arrive. This situation is not good enough and we need to get on top of the problem. In the end I got my wine, but it arrived the day after I wanted it. I was lucky that I had someone to substitute the wine with other wine, but the situation is not good enough and it needs to be improved. Of course, in my own state of Tasmania, the situation becomes terrible. Australia relies on efficient freight systems, and I believe that there is a task force looking at freight systems in Australia. The findings of the task force are crucial to our success in proving our exporting system.

Coming back to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, one of the things that came out during the committee's hearings is the fact that our computer software systems are not up to scratch and that there needs to be a lot of work done to try to work out better schemes and systems. It certainly would be worthwhile to look at the TQM models to see if some of the ideas can be implemented. One of the recommendations in the report is for the government to provide funds for a detailed assessment of the current environment of software development.

There is also a need to seriously promote efficiency among banks and shipping companies, and this is a crucial point. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), gave the wharfies another kick. It is a case of `bash a wharfie', instead of looking at where the problems really are. Failure to look at the problems is one of the major reasons why efficiency in this area is being held back. The banks and the shipping companies must take formal responsibility for promoting greater use of sea waybills. Sea waybills are, of course, a simpler alternative system of documentation than the present system.

The government also has a role in initiating alternatives to international trade and financial documentation, and I believe that the government will take on this responsibility. It is mentioned in the report that it is only in recent times that the government has played a role in trade at the international level by endeavouring to bring together more of this information on an international scale.

Why can we not have standard import and export documentation introduced at all ports around Australia? I am sure that this can happen if there is a will to push to make it happen. The standing committee looked at other reports, including the Ships of shame report, and noted the skulduggery that goes on in world shipping. There are some very bad companies in existence in the world as far as their use of ships is concerned. Given the poor standard of some ships which are in use, these companies seem to have an interest in running their companies inefficiently and ineffectively. Maybe this situation also has something to do with the type of documentation used. Decent companies which operate their businesses in a transparent way should flourish if we get appropriate documentation systems in place.

We need to develop some performance indicators to give us some idea of how our ports are performing, so that we can find out which are our good, efficient ports, and which ones need assistance to come up to scratch.

Our transport systems are vital—not just the ports but our rail system as well. National Rail was reconstructed in February 1993, and has been taking over the commercial responsibilities for operating intermodal terminals, line haulage operations, account marketing and the financial arrangements for invoicing and collecting revenue from these activities.

During our inquiries we heard on a number of occasions that the services provided by National Rail were not meeting the requirements of all its customers. Others have said that they have been reasonably okay. `Reasonably okay' does not give you a very high tick. This is another area where we are moving in the right direction, but there is plenty of potential to improve the service and its reliability.

I remember being at Port Botany and looking at the lack of connections between the rail service and the port. There is a need to link that port to the interstate rail service that now operates around Australia—that is, getting it out of the metropolitan Sydney system, so that you can get a line from your ports and quick access out on to your bigger system to carry you to other parts of the country.

The previous speaker, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), again vented his anger on the wharfies, making them the main issue of concern, whereas I believe that there is a much broader debate concerning the policy changes needed to bring about a more efficient transport system.

Our report argues that the commercial use of EDI, electronic data interchange, in the transport chain would improve things a lot. We also suggested that the shipping and banking industries should accept formal responsibility for promoting the greater use of sea waybills and simpler alternative documentation.

The committee has been promoting these areas for some time. One of the major problems has been the attitude of the banking industry towards the greater use of sea waybills. Banks have negatively portrayed sea waybills as offering inadequate documentation, and have failed to promote the quick releases that can apply under this system.

I understand that the banks must look after their clients, and that they have some concerns regarding ownership of cargo. But in today's world, most of the concerns that the banks have can be overcome. The banks need to take on board their important role in promoting the change to an electronic transfer system by using sea waybills instead of the 400-year-old bill of lading system. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to speak on Warehouse to wharf: Final report in view of the very important issues involved in the report. Firstly, I acknowledge the role of the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, the member for Shortland, Peter Morris, for his understanding of the issues, his capacity to identify the key arguments and his genuine concern about the role of the waterfront and the participation by those users of rail, road and other operators who connect to the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: Committee members were enlightened and encouraged by visits to Container Terminals Australia, Australian Stevedores, National Rail Corporation at Chullora freight terminal in Sydney, South Dynon freight terminal in Melbourne and the port of Geelong. Those visits gave the committee and individual members a clear insight as to the problems on the ground and led to some valuable discussions that brought about the final report. The waterfront, in a public sense, is the villain of the piece in terms of the arguments about the export and import of Australian freight. People can identify with the industrial relations problems, the long history of confrontation at the waterfront, the management and now the technical changes that are taking place, the monopoly position that historically had been enjoyed by those people working on the waterfront and, of course, the identification by political parties and politicians of the suggestion that, if only we could fix up the waterfront, then all our problems would be solved.

However, I make the observation that there are a number of other more complicated factors in relation to the movement of freight from the ships to the warehouse, and the report addresses some of those issues in an attempt to improve the efficiency of the transport of goods. It is the sea-land interface that the report identifies that is so important in improving the movement of goods rather than just identifying the movement from the ship to the waterfront and letting the containers or the goods stay at that location.

The committee identified the self-interest of the service providers—the port authorities, the rail handlers and the road handlers—as being uncooperative because of their concern for their part of the chain of the operation. Likewise, the exporters and importers were concerned with only their responsibility in the operation and there seemed to be little cooperation in trying to improve the total system.

We had some reports on electronic data information in terms of Customs and the AQIS performance and we would be hoping that that would improve. The vehicle booking system provided some interesting problems on the basis that there was not encouragement for people to be in the queues or to get in a vehicle booking system. With the integrated handling there was not good cooperation between the various parties. The committee noted that the Australian Wheat Board and BHP had been able to obtain better working conditions on handling of their particular goods through designated areas.

The committee spent a fair bit of time looking at the vehicle booking system and it seemed a very sensible way to operate that trucks that arrived at the waterfront or the port authority area should have a system whereby they did not spend most of the day in a queue. It came to our attention that this was commercially advantageous, that a person would be paid demurrage if they were standing in a queue and not wearing their truck out driving around the metropolitan area. That vehicle booking system seemed to work quite well, reducing the time from almost days to 40 minutes. Now the time is down to 20 minutes and people can book with some confidence.

In terms of working hours, there were quite clearly evident difficulties in that the waterfronts regard themselves as a 24-hour operation, whereas the warehouses have an attitude of mind that they are open eight hours. Obviously there is a conflict between those two positions. There are peaks in the loading of ships at the waterfront, and if the warehouses are only open eight hours that exacerbates the problem. We would suggest that there be a change of attitude and more cooperation in those hours. For instance, it was brought to our attention that there is late delivery of containers—25 per cent of exporters delivered in the last 24 hours for one particular shipment—which makes it very difficult.

We saw evidence of the interface councils which the committee recommends being a very helpful advantage. In Melbourne, the facilitation committee gets some cooperation between all the port users under the direction of the port of Melbourne, and the evidence was that that was working well. There was progress towards a more efficient system. I think the committee was encouraged by the public hearing in October 1995, where a number of the port users and players were involved and our chairman encouraged the participants to put a point of view. That in itself helped to generate a cooperative attitude.

I mentioned the electronic data interchange. The problems we identified were the cost of the system and the compatibility of the various systems of government and private users. Some of us had a bit of difficulty in understanding the ramifications of the sea waybills and bills of lading. It seems that these systems go back to the days of Nelson and there has been very little change in the way in which this documentation process is undertaken, both internationally and here in Australia. We noted the role of the banks, and some of us were a little concerned that the banks did not play a positive role in ensuring that the payment for and exchange of goods were done in the best possible manner. We also observed that in terms of air freight these arrangements seemed to be much more efficient. In terms of the waterfront performance, the committee was encouraged by the publication of Waterline, which gives some definitive information on the movements of containers and gives some benchmarking.

I now move to the role of the National Rail Authority, National Rail as it is now known, in terms of movement of goods between the state capitals. In my view, the connection of the standard gauge, completed in May 1995, was a major event in the transport history of Australia. The standard gauge was going to be implemented in 1923, I understand, and it was finally done in 1995. I think the significance of this event has been overlooked by the people of Australia, that we now have the ability to move containers and goods from Perth to Brisbane on one standard track.

Obviously, the important thing from the warehouse to wharf perspective is that containers can be moved from the major ports of Melbourne and Sydney to Adelaide or to Brisbane or vice versa according to the shipments and the schedules. None of us needs to underestimate the impact of that national gauge link in the next 10 years, where containers can be moved efficiently, effectively and in a timely fashion. For instance, they can leave Melbourne at 6 p.m. and arrive in Adelaide at 7 a.m. ready for delivery.

In terms of the port charges, the committee notes the state governments' levying of charges in the ports without due consideration to the importance of port facilitation for importers and exporters. For instance, in New South Wales the Maritime Services Board extracted $89.5 million from a total income of $91 million from that particular source, which clearly demonstrates the state government's attitude that they regarded that as a tax gatherer rather than the port of Sydney being a facilitator for exporters and importers. The dividend versus the port facilitation remains a fundamental argument. I just make the observation that the privatisation that has taken place in Victoria in the ports of Portland and Geelong, provided there is not a monopoly position and provided there is genuine competition, may assist with this problem.
Turning to the stevedoring argument, which provides a lot of heat and argument, I note the figures given on page 28 where the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The BIE's 1995 report quotes world best practice container crane rates of 30 moves per hour at Singapore and Hong Kong. Ports of more comparable size to the larger Australian ports, such as Felixstowe, Baltimore, Thamesport, Barcelona, Zeebrugge and Kobe, all achieved crane rates in the range 25 to 29 moves per hour. The BIE reported that these rates compare with 15 to 18.5 moves per hour at Australian ports.

Could I just suggest that we need to be very careful about these comparisons. I have observed the port of Singapore where there is quite massive investment and quite remarkable movements of tonnages and containers without any consideration of onward moves from portside to rail and road traffic.

PARA.TAB: I think there has been somewhat too much concentration on the ability of container moves, rather than the aspects that this report addresses, that is, labour productivity and moving the containers from portside back into the transport chain. I think that, disregarding those movements, we should be looking at whether there is genuine competition between the last two stevedore companies—whether they have more than a cosy monopoly position or whether there is genuine competition between those two stevedores on the Australian waterfront.

Concerning the decline of their performance, we note that in October 1995 the container movements were 18.9 per hour, whereas in September 1992 there were 20.1 per hour, and that compares to the 30 moves in Singapore and Hong Kong. I do not take too much recognition of those factors because there has been a considerable capital investment in the ports for container movements. Vast amounts of money are required for the container cranes and the general layout of these container ports. Hopefully, the capital investment by the two stevedores will enhance the port performance and, more importantly, the industrial relations arrangements—annualising the salaries, improving the productivity, changing the historical industrial relations attitudes at the Australian waterfront and encouraging productivity with the new mechanised equipment—will help the whole waterfront arrangements.

In conclusion, I would like to say that this is a first-class report. We have spoken to most of the key players in the waterfront freight area and I hope that future governments will take into account the recommendations, that people will have a more cooperative attitude towards the movement of freight from the wharfside to the warehouse, and that, little by little, improvements are made. These things do not improve overnight in terms of dramatic changes in technology or attitude, but the recommendations that we have here all warrant careful attention by the user groups. If we could only bring about a change of attitude by those people who are close to the waterfront that would be a key result, as the chairman acknowledges, in producing a better performance by the users of the waterfront and associated facilities.

It is not going to be achieved with some dramatic political decision. It will be this change of attitude and a desire to improve that will help the export and import performance of all those people associated with the waterfront—be they the rail users, the transport operators, the truck drivers or the waterfront workers. I commend the report to the House and again acknowledge the great contribution of the chairman to the whole debate, both in his term as minister and as chairman of this committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak in this discussion on our report Warehouse to wharf: Final report. I appreciate the kinds of remarks that have been made about me by the previous speakers. May I say that whatever I do is simply a response to the team work that comes from our colleagues who are members of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. We are fortunate in that there is very much a team work ethos and there is a high level of participation by members in the work of the committee. That helps to make the whole parliamentary process work better and it highlights the very valuable role that the committee system can contribute to the functioning of the parliament in the interests of the Australia people.

PARA.TAB: The first report of the committee, Warehouse to wharf, was tabled in April l992. As we said at the time, it highlighted the benefits that could be obtained if Australian firms were to make better use of the transport chain from the warehouse to the wharf. We specifically called the report Warehouse to wharf because much of the need for reform is within the operation of the warehouses themselves—the broader question of logistics, how one organises the activities of the warehouse and how one organises all of the operations of all of the links to shipside. It is that last segment where the waterfront itself comes in, but there is an absolute resistance on the part of warehouse operators and users of waterfront services to even consider how they could better utilise the chain.

There is a mismatch of working hours between the shoreside and the shipside. Waterfronts operate 24 hours, virtually every day of the year, yet in Sydney, particularly, warehouses operate less than office hours, Monday to Friday. In fact, we found in the original inquiry that, in some cases, they stipulate the hours—cargo would only be received between the hours of noon and 2.00 p.m. That puts enormous strain upon a transport system to fit into that narrow slot and it brings with it a host of inefficiencies.

Through the original inquiry and through our subsequent inquiry during the term of this parliament, we have been trying to change the culture. As my Deputy Chairman, the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), said a few moments ago, the culture and the attitude must change. It is not so much a matter of the infrastructure not being there; it is a matter of using the infrastructure more efficiently. For that to happen, the attitudes of the users of that infrastructure and the users of those services have to change.

We could not find anybody to appear before our forum on October 13 in Sydney. We could not find anybody who was a real life importer or exporter on a small to medium scale. The industry associations are like sloganeers on how bad the waterfront is. We said to them, `Please, identify for us an individual exporter or importer who is having difficulty so that the committee can address their specific problems and see if we can use that as a model for other importers and exporters to follow.' The ultimate result was that they said, `Sorry, we cannot find anybody.'

We can find many columns of comment about the waterfront. There is an attitude from some people that it is easier to complain about somebody than it is for them to look at their own operations to see how they can better fit in as links in the chain and make the whole system work better. That attitudinal change is resistant: it is not new; it has been there, to my knowledge, since the early 1980s. It was l984 when the Inter-State Commission first looked publicly at this whole process, and the problems of attitude were there then and the inefficiencies were then. I am sorry to say, as my deputy chairman has also mentioned, that nothing much has changed. It is pretty much business as it was back in the 1980s. It is pretty much rhetoric as it was back in the 1980s. Australia loses, severely, out of this.

For the individual small to medium exporters the transport costs are not a priority. They are something like two per cent or three per cent of the total cost of getting the product to their customer—that is, cost of the manufacturing and everything else that goes with it. But when we, as a nation, take those costs collectively they are a very important factor in improving our international competitiveness. The challenge that we have had as a committee, and the challenge that this nation has, is how we get those individual exporters and importers to think and act with some regard to national interest rather than their own simple interests as exporters.

Another matter that remains unaddressed to a large extent is the outdated financial documentary practices. The forms have not changed much. The deputy chairman referred to Nelson; it actually goes back to Captain Cook. The bill of lading that controls the passage of freight through our ports was designed in 1767. The designer of that form really deserves a bicentenary award. More than two centuries later, that form has outlasted all practice, all technology, and 40 per cent of the cargo going through our ports is still on bills of lading.

Aviation, on the other hand, does not have any baggage of history: there are no age-long traditions and practices, smoke filled boardrooms, port wine and cigars to go with aviation; it is much leaner and meaner. Aviation uses waybills, delivery dockets that enable the possession of the cargo to be passed on. In shipping, bills of ladings were used at the time Captain Cook set sail—as detailed in the London Gazette of 25 August 1768—to list not only the possession of the cargo but the title to the cargo. In the same way as banks still have the practice of wanting to sight the original documents, the bill of lading must be sighted so that the possession of the cargo and ownership of the cargo pass at the same time. This practice has to be changed.

We had witnesses before our committee in Sydney on 13 October who were not particularly concerned. They said it was a matter of decision by the customers whether they use a bill of lading or a sea waybill, which is the equivalent of the air waybill. It is simply a delivery docket that passes possession of the cargo but not the title to ownership of the cargo. That issue we have to hammer away at. It can change; it must change so we can streamline the movement of that cargo.

On the question of why anyone wants a bill of lading, those witnesses want a bill of lading for ownership, a title. We want sea waybills used more extensively for speeding the flow of cargo through so that we can try and even out the movement of cargo through ports. One of the problems with the stevedoring operators is that they get peaks and troughs. Cargoes for export invariably arrive late. Twenty-five per cent of cargo arriving at Conaust terminal in Port Botany, we were told, arrives on the last day, but they can start delivering cargo onto the wharf for export up to in some cases five days—but at least three days—before ship sail time. If the cargo comes in evenly, there is a better utilisation of equipment, a smoother operation of equipment, and hours and costs are more evenly spread. When 25 per cent suddenly arrives on the last day and the rest has been held up, in come the inefficiencies. The inefficiencies are very much generated by the exporters themselves. When we look to how we can make more efficient use of the waterfront, it is this chain of events that has to be dealt with.

We recommended back in April 1992 that consultative groups comprising the users of waterfront services as well as the providers of waterfront services be established. We called them `interface efficiency councils' so that all the parties involved in the chain, people at very senior level, could sit around the table and whatever decisions were taken around that table would be implemented.
