That grouping, those discussions, could all work together in coordinating and smoothing that process so we get the maximum efficiency in Australia's interests.

Unfortunately, the Department of Transport at the time passed our recommendation on to the ports. The port authorities, quite obviously, thought, `This is our territory. What are you doing sticking your nose into our territory? We know how best to run the ports.' They do not and they will not. That is the problem. It is true that the Port of Melbourne Authority has done some work and is trying to do something. A lot more could be done, but one has to commend it for the progress that it has made since 1992.

In the case of the port of Fremantle, they have a port liaison task force that has very wide representation. It meets regularly and is headed by Captain David Clarke. They have a troubleshooter and there is a large degree of education of the users of the port so that the users of the port come to understand why it is important to have cargo there early, why it is important to have the documents there ready when the ship arrives and why it is important to timetable the use of road transport.

The users of the road transport and the users of transport to the waterfront can get a better deal for small to medium businesses if they know how the system works, but very few of them have any idea how the system works. What is sad about that is they have not, in the past 3 1/2 years, tried to find out anything about it. We could not get a live exporter to talk to the committee when we had our forum in Sydney on 13 October. We must press on with this. The support of the parliament for the recommendations of the report will have to be persistent. It has been and it must continue.

I turn to the role of ports. I mentioned port authorities in the context of helping to organise the groups. We have re-recommended the establishment of interface efficiency councils. Had they been established, a lot more would have been achieved, so we have recommended that again. Could I say that, if the port authorities do not want to convene them, it does not matter; it is probably better that they do not. The users of the port should do it themselves; it does not have to be the port authorities. The users of the port service could convene a meeting and get on with the job of making the whole system work better.

The other matter concerns electronic data interchange: the use of electronic messaging in the transfer of information to enable cargo to be moved. That is a task that was undertaken initially by the Australian Customs Service, and the Australian Customs Service is the one common link to all of this. There has to be customs clearance coming in and customs clearance going out. It has played a prime role in the introduction of electronic messaging. It and AQIS have both been very active in this but it has been led by the Australian Customs Service.

However, on the other side, on the customer side in the private sector, there has been little involvement. There is a reluctance on the part of customs brokers, freight forwarders, some of the larger customers, to move to electronic messaging. Some parties involved realise that, if they go to electronic messaging, the customer knows precisely where the cargo is. They blame the wharfie, saying, `We would have had your stuff here, it came in yesterday, we collected your money. But it is the wharfies again; we could not get it off the wharf.' A lot of that mythology would be exposed once we move to electronic data interchange, because the customer would just key in and find out immediately where the box is and what the delay is. It will speed the whole process.

There needs to be assistance provided in that area generally because it is the development of the software packages that is involved. The industry is saying that the market is too small. The users are saying, `Realistically, we cannot see the benefits so that we should go ahead and spend money and change our business.' That is because it is not just the introduction of electronic messaging—they have to rejig their business. They have to rejig their business and their whole operations to fit in with that electronic data interchange, better use of the waterfront generally and the transport chain to the waterfront.

We have made a recommendation that `The Commonwealth Government, through the Department of Industry, Science and Technology, fund a detailed assessment of the current environment for software development.' It should pick up not only transport, but also a range of the other industries, because it is a common problem. That is an area, we are convinced, where there will be considerable improvement once it is adopted.

The last matter I want to mention is this: I hope that there is going to be an end to this sloganeering, this rhetoric of `It's the wharfies, it's the wharfies, it's the wharfies.' That is why we said in the report that some of them have been convinced by their own mantra and that, if they chant `the wharfies, the wharfies, the waterfront' enough, somehow things will get better. It is in the hands of the users to get a greater improvement and efficiency and a greater financial return by looking at how the chain works and how they fit into it. By using their muscle—and they have got muscle—in their dealings with the transport providers with whom they do business, they will get a better rate and a better level of service than they are currently getting. I commend the report to the Committee and I thank my colleagues on the committee for their very valuable assistance, particularly the deputy chairman and the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis).
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 27 November, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to make some comments on the second report tabled by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, entitled Oil spills: a response strategy. The problem of oil pollution is one that excites the Australian public and one, when it happens near a built-up area, that the press and the media become very interested in. People become fairly excited and worried and there is a lot of misinformation about the problem, about the impact and about what we should do if an oil spill does take place. Australia has 37,000 kilometres of coastline and an oil spill could take place anywhere along that coastline, which means that a response by a national authority is somewhat difficult. It needs to be executed quickly. It needs to be done efficiently and, obviously, a fair amount of equipment is needed.

PARA.TAB: Our inspection of the facilities at the Australian Marine Oil Spill Centre at Geelong really gave clear evidence of the ways in which you could handle this problem. The equipment and the response strategy that they demonstrated to us was first class. Given a set of circumstances that demanded a reaction from a national point of view, that equipment was available to be flown to any location around the Australian coastline. They had the whole matter in fairly good hands. Contributions for the running of that operation were from the government and from the oil industry. At the time we were inspecting the facility, training was taking place and it seemed to us that, given all the difficulties of mopping up oil after a spill, the equipment, training and methodology were fairly reasonable.

One of the problems that the report identifies is the division of responsibilities and where these oil spills might take place, whether it be at the oil exploration areas—rigs, platforms and pipelines, which are obvious places where a major spill or conflagration might take place; at the oil terminals, where something might go wrong and the oil might spill in the port area; in ports other than the oil terminals; or beyond the three-mile coastal limit, where the jurisdiction by the Commonwealth is somewhat limited.

In terms of the committee's attitude towards the creation of the spill, we made the observation that crew competence in preventing the oil spills in the first instance is a key part of this whole argument. As we say on page 7 of our report:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence shows that most marine accidents are due primarily to the negligence by a ship's crew (AMSA 1993:57). Accordingly, risk assessment plans are made more difficult due to the variables introduced.

We make the point that it is very important that, when we are shipping bulk quantities of oil, the crews handling these ships must be competent, well trained and aware of the consequences of any mishap that might take place when they are in control of that particular vessel.

PARA.TAB: It would seem to me that the oil spill argument has been dominated by the more extraordinary example of the Exxon Valdez where 36,000 tonnes was spilt in Alaska, with the consequent loss of wildlife, pollution to the coastline, and an extraordinary amount of comment by international people. On that occasion, the competence of the crew and the captain were very much in question.

In Australia, the breaking of the bow of the Kirki off the Western Australian coast brought home to most Australians the possibility of a major oil spill within the coastal belt. On that occasion, 17,000 tonnes of light crude oil were spilt from that vessel. The Western Australian coastline was saved by two natural factors—not by any man-made factors. These important points were that it was light crude and the weather conditions were such that the light crude moved out to sea rather than in towards the coastline. The important factor was not the activities of the Australian Marine Oil Spill Centre in conjunction with local people helping to disperse the oil, but the natural conditions.

The response to the oil spills at a national level then moved onto the problem of whether the federal government or the state government has jurisdiction and responsibility for a particular area. In the report we identify statements by a state minister as to the responsibility of the Victorian government compared to the responsibility of the federal government.

The sinking of the Iron Baron and the oil spillage into the Tamar River was again a focal point of the committee's deliberations. That identified a number of problems that we picked up during our discussions. Again, it was evident that the navigational problems at the entrance to the Tamar and the conditions at the time of the grounding of the Iron Baron were a problem in terms of that particular oil spill. Again, my observations of the maps that were tabled showed that the weather conditions made it difficult to mop up the spill. The weather conditions ensured that there was a wide spread of oil around the coastal area along the Tamar River and it was difficult for any authority or individual to clear that area.

Apart from the Iron Baron spill, the committee also looked at some of the other factors that could bring about an oil spill. They list them quite clearly in these terms: risk of collision; risk of grounding; hazards to navigation; seaworthiness of vessels; negligence of crews; size and type of vessel; type and amount of oil carried; traffic density; and environmental factors, including tidal flow and weather, et cetera. Whilst the public at large is concerned, all these factors are taken into account when considering where we might anticipate that there could be an oil spill or, more importantly, what we might do to prevent such an oil spill taking place.
The other important feature that I would like to draw the parliament's attention to is the level of oil spills. I think there is some misinformation. I quote from page 29 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: Data showing the cumulative percentage of spills versus spill size shows that over 80 percent of recorded oil spills are less than 1 000 tonnes.

Let me repeat: over 80 per cent are less than 1,000 tonnes. Whilst the Australian public is legitimately concerned about oil spills, let us remember that a vast majority of those are of a small nature and probably do not cause as much trouble as some people might believe. As the report says:
Only five percent of oil spills are greater than 10 000 tonnes . . . In Australia in the 10 year period to 1992, 98 percent of marine oil spills were less than 7 tonnes . . .
I think that gives a perspective on this argument compared to the Kirki and the Exxon Valdez argument. In terms of recovery, the report says:

A further fact is that international experts advise that it is rare to recover at sea more than 10 percent of the volume of oil spilt . . . In a similar vein, the review of the National Plan, under recommendation 3, sought to inform the community of the limitations in responding to a major oil spill. The review commented `that other than in favourite circumstances current technology does not exist to prevent weather driven oil coming ashore on a coastline or to guarantee prevention of environmental damage and economic loss' (AMSA 1993: 5).

I make the point that, whilst the committee and the audit review looked at the way in which Australia might respond to a major oil spill, from the evidence that we have heard, it will be difficult to handle a major oil spill. Environmental considerations and weather conditions will be important. The public should not be led to believe that, by spending large amounts of money and having the best technology available in the future, we will be able to contain any terrible catastrophe that might happen along the Barrier Reef or near some of our sensitive coastal areas.

PARA.TAB: The key element, as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) would agree, is to ensure that the crews are competent and that captains know exactly where they are along the coastal belt. More care has to be taken to ensure that large tankers do not run into hazards and more precaution has to be taken in some of the identified areas of risk. I note that five areas were identified in Australia—Cape York and Hervey Bay in Queensland, Port Stephens and Lake Illawarra in New South Wales, Cape Liptrap and Cape Otway in Victoria, the western Pilbara and southern ports in Western Australia. AMSA has identified the areas that ships' crews and captains should be wary of, and if they do have large amounts of oil they should be even more careful.

I conclude with the observation, as I have heard the evidence, that the Australian public should not think that we have all the answers. This particular authority has the capacity to handle a large oil spill. There will be a natural attrition and breakdown of the oil in the sea over time. We have a good response mechanism, as technically efficient as we can get at this stage of the known technology. Every effort is being made by the authorities to do their best to address the problem and to be ready to respond to any such catastrophes that might occur. Given all these circumstances, I think it is fair to say that, if there was a major spill, the Australian public should be conditioned to some marine and environmental damage along the coastline if the weather conditions were a factor at the time of the catastrophe.

Let us ensure that the skills of crews are improved, that the transport of oil is in modern ships and that navigational aids and the whole approach to the movement of oil and other chemicals, which we refer to in the report, is done in a safe and careful way so that the Australian public and the Australian coastline is not subjected to the catastrophe we saw in the Exxon Valdez.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to make a contribution to this discussion on the second report tabled by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, entitled Oil spills: A response strategy. I am particularly pleased that you are in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker Newell, as your electorate covers the beautiful beaches on the far north coast of New South Wales. If there was thick, slick black oil on all those beaches instead of golden sand, just imagine what that would do to you, personally, in your surfboard riding, and also to the tourists who contribute so much to the economy of that area.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps no country in the world is ready to respond to a major oil spill. Australia is no exception. But what the country should be doing is taking steps not only to respond to oil spills but to avert them. I think it is true to say that because of the rather freakish nature of all of them, they have not been responded to well. The honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) spoke about the Exxon Valdez. There was a very slow response there, for all sorts of reasons. Two or three years ago I went to the Shetland Islands to have a look at the Braer which went aground there and had the potential to cause disaster to the economy of that part of the world. Again, the response there was not good and they were very lucky because of all sorts of conditions.

I suppose it is the freakish nature of the major oil spills that means that no-one is quite prepared to respond to them adequately. The committee was somewhat surprised that this report dealt just with the response, rather than with measures to avert oil spills. In this regard there are many issues that should be looked at, not least the question of crew competency, and much of my contribution to the debate today will be about crew competency.

Australian seafarers are the best trained in the world, yet most of the seafarers who come to Australia are poorly trained—if trained at all. This is a matter of particular concern. There is often a language barrier between bridge and deck, and also amongst those in the deck crew. More and more charterers are going for the cheapest going rate, leading to the shameful situation where seafarers are often not paid, are abused and, if they complain, are placed on the blacklist held in the Philippines—if they have not ended up disappearing.

This is very much what we are talking about in this report—about crew competency to avert these things. Of interest in this regard is the case of the Cape Star, currently detained in Cairns. The Cape Star is a Panamanian registered sugar freighter which last week went through the compulsory pilotage area of the Great Barrier Reef without a pilot. This, incidentally, is a criminal offence and the master was before the courts in Cairns yesterday.

This came to light only because there was a routine inspection by an AMSA inspector who noticed a lack of markings on the chart. This sorry saga is only one of a number of defects with regard to the Cape Star. The vessel's international oil pollution prevention certificate was out of survey; the main radio was not working properly; wastage of hatch coamings and bulwarks was found; and there was considerable doubt about the vessel's steering gear.

I also understand that the International Transport Federation are concerned about lack of wages in regard to the Vietnamese and Korean crew. I understand that the crew have not been paid for some months. The competency of the crew poses a threat to the Australian coastline because, I would suggest, if the crew members are underpaid or unpaid, untrained, half-starved and physically abused it is not a competent crew. It might be many other things, but it is not a competent crew.

One of the things coming out more and more—and I have had two cases put to me in the past week—are some of these vessels chartered to carry sugar around Australia. At the moment, the Royal Bank of Scotland has taken out an order on the Cape Star and, in relation to the couple of million dollars worth of sugar, no-one knows which of the 11 people involved in it actually owns it. It is there in Cairns at the moment holding up the bulk loading facility.

I remember when we were doing the Ships of shame report that the charterers of the sugar vessels—the Queensland Sugar Corporation—came before us and assured us that they would have nothing to do with ships that were not of top quality. I do not know what has gone wrong in the past two years, but in the last two weeks I have had two or three cases put to me about some of the disgraceful conditions and the conditions for the crew on some of these bulk sugar carriers.

As has been said, Australia has one of the most pristine and precious coastlines in the world. Most people mistakenly believe that the threat to our coastline comes from the huge oil tankers. But it is the bulk oil carried by commercial vessels that poses the greatest threat not only to marine life, but also to the recreational fishing and scuba diving industry, and, indeed, to the coastline.

On 1 November 1995 an incident involving a commercial vessel occurred off Bass Point in my electorate which highlights a constant vigil that must be maintained to protect the Australian coastline from shipping disasters. With your permission, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am going to go into some detail about this event because I know quite a lot about it and it illustrates the problems facing people concerned with shipping and marine pollution around Australia.

The 1,000-tonne unladen vessel Troy D ran aground on the rocks at Bass Point after the vessel overshot the jetty at the Bass Point quarry operated by Pioneer. Pioneer has a contract with Devine Shipping Pty Ltd, which owned the Troy D, to transport concrete aggregate from its Bass Point quarry to Pioneer facilities at Blackwattle Bay.

The drama began when the Troy D was coming alongside the Bass Point quarry jetty to pick up a load of blue metal at about 7.10 p.m. The vessel attempted a trial run at the jetty and, owing to the choppy sea conditions, ended up overshooting the jetty. The crew attempted to put the vessel into reverse but found that reverse would not engage. An anchor was dropped and a further attempt was made to stop the Troy D, but it continued to move forward, dragging the anchor as it went.

The vessel finally came to a stop when it hit rocks a few hundred metres west of the jetty. Two of the Troy D crew made their way to shore at Bass Point by dinghy, to meet police and maritime officials to decide what should be done to remove the vessel from the rocks. It was decided that the vessel should remain stranded on the rocks overnight and that an attempt be made to move it the following morning. The point of all this is that, if that vessel had broken up—which many of us thought it was going to do—the whole coastline of the south coast would have been polluted with oil.

When I became aware that the Troy D had run aground, I immediately called on the New South Wales Minister for Ports, the Hon. Carl Scully, to initiate an immediate inquiry into the incident, the qualifications and skills of the crew, the condition of the vessel and whether all safety procedures had been adhered to. The call was echoed by the Maritime Union and, to the credit of the New South Wales Minister for Ports, he announced the establishment of such an inquiry into why and how the Troy D ran aground on 2 November.

I and other many interested parties await the conclusions of this inquiry with a great deal of interest. Bass Point has a turbulent maritime history. It is a dangerous stretch of water, with rocks and reefs ready to inflict as much damage as possible on shipping vessels. The local paper ran quite an extensive coverage on the Troy D incident under the headline `Bass Point notorious for undoing sailors of old'. It went into some detail about the ships that have gone aground there.

Some might say that discussing in such detail the Troy D incident is a storm in a teacup, but it is an issue of importance because it starkly demonstrates the need to establish, and strictly adhere to, the very best Australian and international seafaring standards of crew competence, safety procedure and vessel seaworthiness. The 60-miler trade has been serviced over the past 40 years by reputable shipowners who have incorporated the necessary level of safety and shipping technology and have ensured that suitably qualified crews on award conditions were engaged for this work.

It seems that the present owner of the Troy D, Brett Devine, does not share the same interests in safety and the employment of satisfactorily qualified crews. Mr Devine seems intent on pursuing his simple, bloody-minded, anti-union agenda. Fifteen hours after the Troy D hit the rocks and was stuck at Bass Point, Mr Devine came ashore and, as the Illawarra Mercury described it, tucked a $100 bill into the grimy hand of a seafarer and told him to get three chickens, a couple of loaves of bread and some cigarettes. In the meantime, he publicly slammed the Maritime Union of Australia, its Port Kembla officials, the tugboat crews and, it seems, everyone in sight who did not agree with his view of shipping operations.

Mr Devine has had a reluctance to negotiate an industrial agreement with the Maritime Union and is absolutely opposed to the incorporation into his employment practices of schedule 10, which specifies that seafarers should be engaged from the pick-up. In a letter dated 13 October 1995 to Mr John Garrett of the Maritime Union of Australia, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Just to conclude, we are interested in concluding a fair and reasonable agreement with the MUA and other unions, if necessary.
Some remark—`if necessary'! Of course it is necessary. It is what the Maritime Union has been asking for and it is something that Mr Devine has tried to bluff and bluster his way out of.

PARA.TAB: Because the Troy D is engaged in intrastate trade, Devine Shipping Pty Ltd does not have to meet the conditions and the provisions set out in the Navigation Act. Mr Devine is required only to meet provisions contained in the Commercial Vessels Act of New South Wales, which is something I have asked the New South Wales Minister for Ports to address. The Commercial Vessels Act does not provide for the employment of ABs or similar ratings. As far as the crew is concerned, the act provides for the employment of deckhands, and the minimum requirement for a ticket is a two-week sea and safety survival course at the local TAFE college.

While the Troy D was still stuck on rocks at Bass Point I went out there to see for myself what was involved in the salvage operations and to see what the condition of the vessel was. Having seen quite a few vessels, and having been aboard quite a few also, the first thing that struck me was how old and antiquated this vessel was. I am advised that it has hatch boards and tarps in place. This is confirmed by Mr Devine in his letter to Mr John Garrett, to which I referred earlier. One would assume that a high degree of skill and competence was required in order to operate the vessel safely and efficiently.

Upon investigation by the MUA it was discovered that the Troy D crew did not have the minimum requirements to operate the vessel safely and efficiently. In fact, an application to the Waterways Authorities by Devine Shipping resulted in an exemption being granted to the crew to operate without the minimum formal qualifications. I ask: why was this exemption granted? Why was this crew granted an exemption to operate this vessel without the minimum formal qualifications?

When the Troy D commenced to trade, the MUA quite properly slapped on a ban, which included the refusal to supply a pilot to the vessel. The dispute was referred to the New South Wales Industrial Commission for determination. The bans took immediate effect, but Mr Devine found it extremely difficult to defend his position before the commission. I understand that he became so frustrated with the proceedings that he sacked his legal representatives and continued proceedings himself.

Various accusations have been made against tug crews in Port Kembla in the wake of the grounding of the Troy D. Mr Devine, and Michael Seward, a naval architect and manager and director of Seward Maritime Marine Consultants and Contractors, have made public allegations which in my view slander tug crews in Port Kembla and the tug company Wallace Tugs.

Michael Seward, in an article in the Illawarra Mercury said that for the union to deny the company the use of a tug to help refloat the boat off rocks was an act of absolute lunacy. The fact is that the tug members in Port Kembla stood by with full crews in anticipation of being called upon to assist in refloating the Troy D. A media release, issued by the general manager of Wallace Tugs Pty Ltd, Alan Roberts, puts the claims made by Mr Devine and Mr Seward in a more truthful perspective. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Wallace Tugs is concerned at statements made by a spokesmen of the owners of the Troy D which appeared in the Illawarra Mercury on 9 November. The spokesman claims that the Troy D was denied the use of a tug from Wallace to help refloat the ship from rocks off Bass Point, and that somehow this was because of a union desire to classify the rescue operation as salvage. This is totally untrue.

PARA.TAB: At no time did the owner of the Troy D contact Wallace Tugs for assistance, which is amazing considering the spokesman's claim that the vessel's fuel tanks were at risk of rupturing and spilling into the sea. When the Port Kembla Harbour Master asked Wallace Tugs to assist the vessel, the Wallace tug sailed immediately to Bass Point.

There was no objection from the unions to this rescue voyage. In the event, the Troy D refused assistance of the Wallace tug. We can not comment on the dispute generally between the owner of the Troy D and the Maritime Unions. We do object, however, to wild accusations about the actions of Wallace tugs and to associated criticisms of the unions, which are simply not true.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Devine and Mr Seward cannot even get their stories straight.

PARA.TAB: When the grounding occurred, I called for an immediate cessation of loading of blue metal into a vessel of this kind at Bass Point. I am pleased that the general manager of Pioneer Bass Point jetty agreed with me. At present, I understand that the Troy D is in dry dock at Newcastle. Devine should not be permitted to recommence shipping on the 60-miler trade run until there are fully certified crews on board the Troy D. Safety requirements as per the Navigation Act should be implemented and union crews should be employed under the appropriate award.

The Australian coastline is much too important to be subjected to the operation of tin-pot commercial vessel operators who have no regard for the condition of their vehicles, the competence of their crew and the safety procedures which are established by legislation and regulation. Australia has led the world in ridding our coast of `ships of shame'. It is time we started leading the world in ridding our coastline of the untrained crews now operating there. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for their report on this very important issue. I would like to particularly congratulate both the previous speaker, the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), and the chairman of the committee, the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), for their work over many years highlighting these very important issues.
—Friends of seamen.
—That is exactly right. They are not only that, but also the friends of a very important and fragile part of the Australian environment: that is, the Great Barrier Reef, in my electorate.

PARA.TAB: Of course, a wide range of issues have been canvassed by the member for Throsby. I certainly endorse his comments, especially in relation to the conditions that some crews have to suffer on these `ships of shame'. Unfortunately, we have still got them plying this coast. I would certainly endorse his comments.

The matter that concerns me, being the member for Leichhardt, is the danger of oil spills, and, in particular, the effect that any potential oil spill would have on both the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait, which are in my electorate. These are very important issues.

The protection of the Great Barrier Reef from oil spills is obviously important for ecological reasons. It is listed on the World Heritage list. It one of the great wonders of the world, and certainly something we would not want to see damaged.

Of course, flowing from that, any oil spill would cause great economic damage to the region that I represent. The Great Barrier Reef is an important part of the Far North Queensland economy. It is, again, stating the obvious to say that people come to Far North Queensland to visit both the Great Barrier Reef and the Wet Tropics World Heritage areas. Any damage to either of them obviously represents an economic threat to Far North Queensland. I think it is true to say that there is a general consensus in my electorate that that is the case. There is no doubt that the tourism industry recognises that the Great Barrier Reef has to be protected, for all those reasons that I have stated.

It is of great concern, as the honourable member for Throsby also mentioned, that this week we have got the unfortunate example of a Panamanian registered ship, the 154 1/2-metre Cape Star, breaching the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act by failing to employ a marine pilot to guide the ship through the reef.

I congratulate the AMSA surveyor, Mike Kinley, who, on a routine port state control inspection of the Mourilyan Bulk Sugar Terminal on Friday, noted the lack of position marks on the charts. When the master of the Cape Star failed to produce a copy of the pilot's certificate, the Federal Police were informed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rightly so!

—And rightly so, as the member for Throsby says. The captain has been charged under section 59 of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, which makes it an indictable offence to not carry a pilot through the inner reef. The matter is, of course, before the courts in Cairns. The deputy chief of the Queensland Sugar Corporation, Mr Michael Bosscher, says the QSC was not aware of an association between the ship and Adriatic Tankers, which, I am informed, has had a string of vessels arrested around the world in the past 18 months.
—Yes.

—The honourable member for Throsby confirms that. AMSA says the ship is not unseaworthy but the radio was not operating properly and there are suspected problems with the steering mechanism of the ship. This is just a disgrace, given the fragility of that Great Barrier Reef Marine Park environment in particular.

PARA.TAB: The International Transport Workers Federation is also investigating allegations that the Korean and Vietnamese crews on the ship were owed back wages. Again, we have problems about the crew as well as the problem about the state of the ship.

The penalties under section 59 of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act provide for a penalty of up to $10,000 for the master and up to $50,000 for the shipowner. I take this opportunity to call for an increase in those penalties—in particular, the minimum penalty. If we are going to deter masters of ships from breaching the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and other maritime regulations to do with safety—and especially safety from oil spills—we have got to be tough. There is no doubt: we have got to be tough. If these sorts of events are occurring, it is obvious that the penalties are not tough enough.

I also call on the government to make the charterers liable for the breaches which occur because of lack of pilotage. It is not good enough to say that we do not know the connection or that we do not know these things are going on. These matters are far too serious for the Australian corporations who charter these unseaworthy vessels to escape liability.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the cargo owners.

—And the cargo owners, as the honourable member for Shortland reminds me. It is essential that we strongly deter any breach of maritime regulations—in particular, breaches which may occur in the Great Barrier Reef area. I hope that the government will act swiftly on this problem, because we do not want to see a repeat of the problem which we saw in Cairns this week and we certainly do not want to see the possible consequence of this problem—an oil spill in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.
—A most pristine area.
—It is a most pristine area, as the member for Throsby says. This area is a very important area for Australia both ecologically and economically.

PARA.TAB: There is another section of my electorate which would be devastated by an oil spill—the Torres Strait area. I was greatly concerned when I spoke with the representatives of the Torres Shire Council who participated with AMSA in an exercise in relation to oil spills a few months ago. They informed me that, if there is an oil spill in the Torres Strait, Horn Island airstrip is not able to take the planes which are necessary to bring equipment to dissipate the oil spill. I understand that the planes would have to come from Geelong. They would have to fly into Weipa, unload onto a barge and then travel around to Horn Island. If there is an oil spill in the water surrounding the outer islands of the Torres Strait, the planes would have to travel even further by barge.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long would that take?
—The honourable member for Throsby asks me how long this would take. I suggest that it would take too long.
—He doesn't know.

—Who would know? It would certainly take too long. You could not get a barge from Weipa to Horn Island in anything less than half a day. Of course, getting it out to the outer islands depends on which outer island you are talking about. If you are talking about Murray Island or one of the further islands or any of the reefs which are a long way away, it might take a day to get the equipment from Weipa to the spill. This delay does not take into account the time that it takes to get an aircraft from Geelong to Horn Island.

PARA.TAB: Oil spills are of great concern, and I again call on the federal government and all other levels of government to seriously look at upgrading Horn Island airstrip so that it can take the necessary aircraft to bring in dispersant and the other vital equipment which is necessary to deal with an oil spill. If we do not make these changes, then an area which is one of the most beautiful parts of Australia and one of the most beautiful and ecologically significant parts of the world may be irreparably damaged.

I raised in the parliament recently the issue of the potential pollution of the Torres Strait by the Ok Tedi mine. On this occasion I said that, if there is any pollution which affects the marine life of the Torres Strait, the pollution will also affect the health of the people who live in the Torres Strait area. This situation would apply equally in relation to an oil spill, because the people of the Torres Strait depend largely on seafood for their basic diet. If there is an oil spill or any pollution from the Ok Tedi mine in the future, the health of the people who live in the Torres Strait area would be threatened. We all know about the health statistics for people in areas such as the Torres Strait; they are not good at all. Therefore, an oil spill would not only threaten the people of the Torres Strait economically; it would also affect their health.

These issues are very serious; they are probably some of the most serious issues to come before the parliament. I suggest that, if we do have an oil spill, it will be too late to look over these debates and to say, `Oh, well, we should have listened to the honourable member for Throsby. We should have listened to the honourable member for Shortland. We should have done what they said.'

TALK.START.PARA: —And the honourable member for Leichhardt.

—I thank the honourable member for his compliment. I have been in this place for a short time, but both the members I have spoken to have fought this fight for a long time. We cannot allow the problem to be ignored.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that when you talk about the area of the Great Barrier Reef north of Cairns, or areas in Australia which are very sparsely populated, there is probably very little a person can do if there is an oil spill compared with what one can do in the more populated areas of Australia. That is a great fear that I have and that is why it is very important that the recommendations of the Ships of shame report and all the matters that are raised by the honourable members for Throsby and Shortland are attended to. That is the only and ultimate way that we are going to make sure that oil spills are prevented in those areas.

Make no mistake about it. When you look at my electorate, up the coast between Cooktown and Bamaga, there is the Aboriginal settlement at Lockhart River and a small settlement close by at Portland Roads and that is it. If an oil spill occurred there, we would not have the manpower to deal with it. That is why the state of the vessels and the crews is a very important issue.

In conclusion, again I commend the committee for its report. It is another step on the way to preventing oil spills but, to quote from another organisation, we have to be eternally vigilant against any thought of having oil spills on any part of the Australia coast, especially that very pristine and beautiful part of the coast that I represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement without closing the debate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to add to my statement to the House last Monday in respect of our report Oil spills: A response strategy. When we say `oil spill', the average person automatically reacts `Great Barrier Reef'. When we say, `Shipwreck', they think, `Oil'. I want to expand on both those reactions.
—I think of people too.
—I beg your pardon?
—I think of people too. I think of death.

—I thought you were interposing something useful. I will move on. Pollution of the sea is from many sources and there is much lack of understanding of the forms of pollutants. If we look at the contribution that oil makes to polluting the sea, some 10 to 12 per cent of the oil that is spilled in the sea from tankers is recovered. It is very much a mirage or mirrors exercise. People see enormous efforts to recover oil from the sea but in the major oil spills only a very small amount of it is recovered. That is for a number of reasons: the difficulty of recovering the oil, the weather conditions at the time, and the evaporative quality of the oil—if it is a lighter oil, much of it evaporates. If the sea is rough, the oil is dispersed and broken up, depending on the currents and winds. It may be humanely impossible to recover the oil. That is just to describe the reality of situations that occur.

PARA.TAB: If we look to the nature of the spills, we find that 98 per cent of oil spills in Australia in the 10-year period to 1992 were less than seven tonnes, 1.75 per cent were between seven and 700 tonnes and the remaining 0.25 per cent were greater than 700 tonnes. That may put it into perspective.

If we look at oil polluting of the sea, 12 per cent of all oil pollution is accounted for by tankers. It comes from tanker spillages. General vessel operations—the washing of tanks, the spillage over the side, the ordinary running operations of general vessels, not tankers—account for 33 per cent. A major and often overlooked source of oil pollution of the sea is from industrial discharge and urban run-off. That accounts for some 37 per cent. The largest single category is industrial discharge and urban run-offs.

On afternoons when the rain starts to fall and oil glistens on the surface of the road, those of us who are in coastal environments know that, sooner or later, that oil will reach the sea. That problem can be readily addressed without any expensive oil recovery strategy, simply through better housekeeping. Certainly, there needs to be a much stronger effort in respect of industry operations to make sure that oil is not discharged into sewers and drains and everything else.

In New South Wales, the amount of oil that is legitimately disposed of is far less than the amount that is used. So there is a missing component. Whether it goes illicitly down a drain or into the sewer or into some land mass where eventually it finds its way into the aquifer or into the sea, it goes somewhere. It is a much bigger problem than just ships.

When we turn to ships, it is a major world problem. Australia is particularly vulnerable because of the length of our coastline and the sensitivity of our coastline. However, fundamental to the whole approach to containing oil spills and dealing with the problem is prevention. It is priority one. The main emphasis has to be upon making sure that ships are competently operated and that they know the areas that they are moving into.

Just in the last few days we have seen the case of the Cape Star transiting the Great Barrier Reef without a pilot on board, and yet it is global knowledge and global practice through all forms of international shipping that piloting is compulsory in any movement through the Great Barrier Reef. It is the operation of ships and the competency of the crews that are the major contributors to collisions, groundings and sinkings of vessels.

Any sort of analysis of those causes shows that 80 per cent of ship groundings, collisions and sinkings result from human factors. By human factors, we mean the actions of human beings. Competency is the key part in that, along with ensuring that vessels are crewed by people who are competent to perform their tasks—people who can read charts, who can manage the wheel and who can ensure that it does not go over the side. It is amazing how many ships come into Australia with clean tanks and depart with dirty tanks, but when they reach the next port the tanks are clean. That is illegal under international maritime law, but it happens. Trying to detect it is much more difficult.

What is causing a great deal more worry—and we have covered it in our report, to an extent—is the greater use of single-voyage permit ships: foreign ships that are doing a voyage between two Australian ports. The use of single-voyage permits has virtually exploded in the last few years. In 1994-95, 434 foreign ships transited the Australian coast on single-voyage permits. In other words, they picked up cargo in one place in Australia and took it to another place in Australia. Of those 434 single-voyage permit foreign vessels, 70 were oil tankers—and that covers oil tankers of all types—63 were dry bulk carriers, and 301 were general cargo containers.

People rhapsodise about oil and the spillage of oil from the grounding and rupturing of a tanker, but the offensive oil product is the bunker oil of the ship. That does not need to be from a tanker. With the recent grounding of the Iron Baron on Hebe Reef at the entrance to the River Tamar, the offensive element was the bunker oil of the ship. It is much more difficult to deal with: it is thicker; it is more offensive; it has a more detrimental effect on the marine environment; and it is very much affected by water temperature. In the case of the Iron Baron, where the water temperature was 11 degrees, the bunker oil very quickly formed itself into large lumps which made it all the more difficult to gather and to dispose of. Thus the care and supervision of single-voyage permit ships, in my view, must be greatly accelerated.

At the moment, if paperwork is presented showing that a vessel is competent to perform the task for which its use is sought, it is approved by the Department of Transport. That is not good enough. What we have learnt in this country—and what the rest of the world has learnt from us—is that competency is the prime factor in the operation of ships and the condition of the vessels themselves.

We had the case, a couple of years ago, of the APJ Anand, on the west coast of Australia. She loaded wheat in Geraldton and came round to Mackay. That vessel should not have been at sea. It was in an absolutely disgraceful condition. But, because it was on a single-voyage permit, it had not been subject to compulsory inspection.

There is a very tough targeting system that applies to foreign ships—bulk carriers destined for overseas ports—loading in Australian ports. The same tough regime does not apply to foreign ships operating on single-voyage permits. It ought to. It is my belief that they are posing an increasing danger to our coastline, our fisheries and our sensitive and delicate marine environments.

Let us move on from the nature of oil spills, how oil spills come about, and the emphasis having to be upon prevention. As I said earlier, when one says `shipwreck', people say `oil'. I put this to the Committee: the chemicals that are carried on board vessels can be much more damaging. Sulfuric acid is one. There are a whole range of oil products and a whole range of chemical products.

These are some of the chemicals that were transported in Australian waters in 1992: sulfuric acid, sodium cyanide, ammonium nitrate, sulfur, propane, butane, caustic soda, soda ash, resin, fertiliser, and explosives. The focus is always on oil, but there are much more damaging ones. We had, back in September 1991, a Panamanian registered tanker loaded with tallow. Tallow can be extremely difficult to deal with. I say to the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) that if one drops 6,000 tonnes of tallow in the Great Barrier Reef one is going to have very difficult problems recovering that and preventing the damage it might cause. It is quite offensive. Even if it is in drums, it is a difficult cargo to handle if there is wreckage and spillage.

The Jovian Loop was a Panamanian registered tanker carrying just over 6,000 tonnes of tallow. It ran up on Unison Reef. The captain immediately sought to put the ship in reverse and pull it off the reef, which is absolutely taboo under international shipping practice. The first thing to do is assess damage, secure the ship and try to secure any punctures that may have been made in the hull. As good fortune had it, they ran up on the reef, the hull was not breached, no cargo was spilt, they got it into reverse and they eventually got off.

I mention that because I want Committee members to have a very deep think about the potential damage that would be involved if something like that happened with caustic soda, cyanide or sulfuric acid on board. It is not just oil.

Let us come back to oil. How does one attribute responsibility? There is oil discharged around the coastline, in the seaways, illegally. Tankers wash their tanks on the way to or the way from Australia, spilling oil overboard. That generally comes from poor practices, but there can be breakages or ruptures in shipboard gear. The difficulty, when one locates an actual oil spill, is in trying to track that back. After about 12 days, it is fairly difficult to try to identify the characteristics of the oil.

In 1991, the Newcastle Port Corporation started a sampling procedure. All ships entering the port of Newcastle since l991 have had their bunker oil and bilge oil sampled. The Newcastle Port Corporation employees go on board in the normal course of their duties to connect phones and other services, so they are on the ship anyway. They take with them a plastic bottle which costs $1, and they take a sample of the bilge oil in the ship and a sample of the bunkers. If there is a spillage later on, they have samples there by which the spilt oil can be identified and used as evidence in the case of a prosecution.

TALK.START.PARA: —We should have that in every port in Australia.

—We recommended that that practice be adopted. It is very simple and it costs the port corporation about $7 per sample, because their officers are on board the vessel anyway. All it takes is a plastic bottle which they take back, label and put on the shelf. If nothing happens within a month, they dispose of the sample. The important thing is that it operates in two ways. Firstly, the sample is there as evidence, in case prosecution should be needed. Secondly, it has been one hell of a deterrent because there has not been an oil spill on the coast near Newcastle since.

PARA.TAB: The message goes direct to the captain of the vessel on board the ship that the port official has taken a sample not of all the oils but of the two key oils, the ones most likely to be emptied over the side or pumped out of the bilges. This creates an awareness in the minds of the crew of that vessel that we are watching it. Some people might ask how we would know there had been an oil spill. The resident population is absolutely vigilant on the coastline and, if anything looks like oil, telephone calls are immediately made to the port corporation and the matter is checked out. There has not been an oil spill since that date.

I recommend the report to the committee and to the parliament. I particularly thank my committee colleagues for their contribution: the deputy chairman, the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur); the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor); and the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). We had a good team working on this and I thank them and the committee staff. I commend the report and its recommendations not only to the chamber but also to the government.
Debate (on motion by Mr Atkinson) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

PARA.TAB: Debated resumed from 23 October, on motion by Mr Price:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Looking at the report on the provision of academic studies and professional military education to officer cadets and officers of the Australian Defence Force entitled Officer education: The military after next and looking at the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I think that this has been a very challenging exercise. When I look through the recommendations that we have achieved out of this report, I see it as being a very comprehensive and far-reaching report, one that looks at the problems that we are going to face in the future.

PARA.TAB: In no small part, we need to thank the original chairman of the committee, the member for Chifley (Mr Price) for the direction—if one likes to put it in those terms—and focus that he gave to the committee in the early stages to concentrate on what has actually come out as an excellent report. It is also important to recognise the contribution of the chairman, the member for Fowler (Mr Grace), and also the staff participants: Gillian Gould, who was secretary until July l995, followed by Matthew Mason-Cox; and the inquiry staff, Peter McLay and the committee adviser, Wing Commander Ken Given.

When one recognises that the whole process of change in the defence forces is a costly process, it is fairly clear that we need to look at specific areas, not the least of which is professional officer education—as opposed to officer training, and there are very clear and distinct differences between the two. I do not exclude training from the cost areas we need to look at, but it is a separate area and not part of this particular report.

It is important that we have a look at what it is that we do in officer training at all levels and what the importance of those areas is, and try to come up with innovative ways in which we can improve this training process. It also has to be recognised, in view of the established process and the traditions that particularly apply in the military forces, that it is somewhat difficult to come up with ways and changes rapidly that will not have some implications for the traditions and the ways that things have been done in the past. In the services, of course, a great deal of emphasis is placed on tradition and the ways that things are done.

We are in a changing world and, as a result, we really do need to look at a number of these changes that are put into place. Having spent some time in the services and gone through one of the officer training establishments, I found it interesting to sit and look at the training processes and the resultant officers who came out of Skyville, Portsea and Duntroon—from an army perspective—and I really had to do some soul-searching and ask myself what the difference was in the result that we were producing.

I had to ask: is there a significant enough difference in result, based on the dollars that we put in, to justify maybe stopping and having a look at things being done in a different way? If one looks around at some of the senior officers that we have, a commander of the ADF was a Portsea graduate and, on the basis of that, he has obviously shown a lot of military skill in the process of getting to there. But, on that basis, the question I asked myself was whether, if Duntroon was set up as the key establishment—and we are now starting to see a lot of Portsea graduates flow into senior positions, simply because the process has required that period for some of these people to get through to those positions—there is any major difference in the process of education.

I have come to the conclusion—and I think the committee has, too, when one looks at the recommendations that we have agreed on, even if for different reasons—that a series of education stages are needed, but that maybe what we need to do is refocus and look at it in a different way. The important part of that came out in recommendation 16 when we were looking at the undergraduate sponsorship and saying that we would like to see 1,000-odd places provided and the opportunity for people to go through the training systems to start with in order to enable them to be assessed for the military before the final commitments were made.

That process is a bit of a two-way street. Firstly, it gives the potential officer training cadet the opportunity to have a look at the way the military system works, and secondly, it gives the ADF an opportunity to see whether that person is suitable. I think if that sponsorship system is implemented it will work quite well. I believe it is something that we should encourage because it is not just the academic requirements that we need of our senior military people; we also need a sense of being able to assess the situation and you cannot always pick that until you have put these people through the process. It seems a fairly cost-effective way of doing that.

The other important part of that is that we have seen many people talk to us about the value of the defence academy based on having the triservice involvement there and therefore having interaction between the three services. While I do not want to cut across what the recommendations say with respect to the academy, we have had that element built in. But I think the important part in all of that is that, in the future, there will need to be far more interaction with the general community.

The interaction of people going through the university streams out into other fields, and not just into other services, will be just as significant. In fact, it will probably be more significant because the interaction that will be able to be achieved will not be talking to somebody in another defence service who is having just as much difficulty getting the dollars together for what they need as you are in your service, but the opportunity to talk to somebody in a business outside who may be at the leading edge of a particular technology. That will provide an opportunity to interact and communicate.

To me, that in itself will be significant in the future development and direction of our services. Realistically, at the rate technologies are moving, it is almost impossible to expect that our defence funding can keep up with the changes of these technologies. But it is important to know what technologies work, what technologies are usable. That aspect of it has been fairly important, certainly in the way that I have thought through the process of that sponsorship working. I think that will be significant if it is adopted.

I refer to recommendation 11, the request for ADF to do a feasibility study into establishing a triservice college with single service elements and replacing the single service precommissioning colleges. In effect, that also provides that interaction that the academy has had by bringing all of the people from the individual service colleges together to give them the experience of the interaction which will not only help them in their military careers but also, as they get further up the ranks, help them to understand and interact between the services. That will have considerable significance as time goes by.

I do not think anybody could have done anything but look very closely at the costs of training a cadet at the academy. The recommendation that we have processed on this has been, in fact, a realistic one. I know that there will be some people on the committee who have concerns about that but I think that, when one looks at the costs of training cadets through the defence academy, as opposed to training them through the university system, it is very hard to justify the difference in costs.

My view is that the interaction in the university will be significant. I suspect that my view on that comes in part from my having got out of the defence forces in my late twenties and found that the outside world was substantially different. I found that it took me probably six to 12 months to adjust and fit into the civilian way of doing things, having joined the services at a very young age. That, I suppose, has been part of the reasoning for my view that this relationship with the normal, everyday university student is important in the whole process of this education.

It was saying to me that a lot of people who go into the military systems at a very young age, work through the system, understand the military traditions and understand the military way of doing things have not got that experience of the outside world. When it comes to a time where that is needed—and the time they need that obviously is when they need to put their military skills to the test—those people need to understand the way that those around them in the community think. That part of it is significant. With respect to that, the recommendation that looked at particular parts relating to Australian citizenship and the whole role of Australian government and the way that it works is a significant addition to the training that is being proposed.

It is important also to look at the accreditation processes for officers. Many of the people who spend their life in the services find that the courses that they have done do not really help them in the outside world. A lot of these people, by virtue of their age, are required to go out and look for jobs. Sometimes, because they have spent years in the services, it is at an age where it is very difficult to get acceptance outside.

Having said that, I think the professional training—and it is good professional training that the military services provide for these people—gives people a leading edge in some areas, but the qualification interchange does not always work as well as it could. I think it is significant and important to get accreditation wherever possible. People should have the opportunity to gain diplomas and degrees for the training they undertake inside the military establishment. I think this is a significant and important aspect for those people.

Generally, the processes that have been looked at by this report will, if adopted, provide substantially improved military officers with a far broader understanding of the community around them. It will also provide some cost savings and the opportunity for funds to go into other areas. Page 125 of the report looks at the commercial support program. Simply by sitting down and doing it better, a saving of $98 million has been achieved in that program. Better working arrangements between the 2,200 military people and the 980 civilians has meant that the money saved in this area has freed up people to go into the fighting elements of the services. We are grappling with these issues to ensure that we have sufficient levels in these areas. The achievement in that area shows that interaction in military officer training can also be significant.

One of the difficulties involved here is that it really has to be looked in the long term. There are also some senior officer training elements in this program, and I have not specifically addressed those in my comments today, partly because other people will be addressing these elements. I have more input to the junior officer training level. We are really not going to know, for some 20 to 25 years down the track, how effective some of these changes are going to be in this area of junior officer training, simply because it will take that length of time to see whether some of these people make it to the very senior ranks of our forces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I thank the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) for his thoughtful contribution to the debate this afternoon. His contribution exemplifies the background, the interest and the composition of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which was charged with the responsibility of following the reference from the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to look at the whole issue of officer education.

PARA.TAB: Very generous and well deserved mention has been made of the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who, as chairman of the committee, had a profound influence on the direction and the recommendations in this report. The Defence Subcommittee is very fortunate to have people such as the member for Chifley, who largely had responsibility for chairing the subcommittee. The new chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace), has a large defence establishment within his electorate. The deputy chairman of the committee, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), served as Minister for Defence for a number of years. From 1989-90, I served as Minister for Defence Science and Personnel.

There are other people, such as the member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who had a distinguished period of service in the Royal Australian Navy. There are a number of other people with this sort of background, interest and experience, and these people have helped to make up an extraordinarily effective defence subcommittee. As I am prone to say to stress this point to the general public, parliamentary committees play an extraordinarily valuable role which is not often necessarily understood by the community at large. The committee system plays a valuable role, and it does so, in most cases, in a bipartisan way. The committee system results in reports like this report by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which are very thought provoking and which will, hopefully, lead to major analysis and, therefore, change into the future.

This report is a landmark report which challenges some of the contemporary issues of officer education and training. It is important that we do challenge some of these views—not necessarily because we are critical of training and education per se, but because we are dealing with a unique profession. It is an honourable profession and it is an extraordinarily demanding profession. Major-General Gower, in evidence to the committee, made the point that the profession is unique because its members do not engage in their primary profession—war fighting—on an everyday basis. He said that, therefore, the problem facing the educators and trainers of military professionals is not only to prepare them for the eventuality of war fighting, in itself a difficult and demanding task, but also to fit them for the multitude of other tasks which military professionals will perform in peace time. This is the nub of the challenge in any issue associated with the education of military professionals.

The member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) picked up on a theme about which I intend to make some comments—the issue of the appropriateness of training in an institution which is primarily dedicated to officer education. I refer, of course, to the Australian Defence Force Academy, ADFA.

The real dilemma for the people who are concerned with following through this report at governmental level and responding to some of the recommendations that we have made is essentially to make a judgment about the appropriateness of the training in this sort of institution: an organisation which was set up at a time when there was great hostility towards military education and the profession of arms. It was set up in the post-Vietnam period when, without going into the rights or wrongs of this particular period, there was a very negative view taken of people who served in the profession of arms. As a result of this situation, a separate institution was established. It is probably almost 20 years since the original timing of the decision to think about a separate institution, and it is, therefore, appropriate that we review the decision. The committee has provided a great deal of thought-provoking comment in its report and also some profound recommendations.

That is one issue. On the other hand, of course, if it is decided to follow the committee's recommendations and, therefore, to look at professional education in its broader sense through civilian universities, then the obvious comparisons and contrasts have to be made as to the appropriateness of this training for people who wish to serve in the Australian Defence Force past their secondary education.

When the member for Isaacs spoke along these lines, I could not help but think that what he is really saying is that it is almost analogous to the situation when we ask, `Is it appropriate for someone to go straight from school into a seminary without any sort of worldly experience?' This is the only sort of analogy I can think of in terms of the current arrangements that we have for people who go, for example, into the Australian Defence Force Academy.

This is an interesting philosophical issue. I am sure that defence planners and the chiefs of staff and their advisers, along with the Minister for Defence—who will, obviously, have to respond in time to this report—will have a great deal of thinking to do about some of these issues. On balance, they will probably be very grateful for the committee's work in challenging the contemporary situation as far as officer education and training is concerned.

I think the mere cover of the report is a challenging thing in itself. Three officers—two male and one female—are shown. Underneath that fairly straightforward picture, there is a blurred illustration of three people in the services which suggests—perhaps in a form of imagery, at least—a blurring of roles and responsibilities and, of course, a questioning of officer education in the military after next.

This is the real challenge for the people who are our defence planners and who are preparing the military after the next: how do we actually train someone? How do we develop the skills, and how can we have the transfer of training required to be able to cope with a situation that is going to be radically different from a military engagement 20 years earlier?

It is almost bizarre, sometimes, to see some of the movies that were made at the time just after World War II, and to see the machinery that was used in that war. Just a few years on, one could look at some coverage of the equipment that was used in the Vietnam War, which was the first war that was really televised into our living rooms. One could even make comparisons between that and the conflict in the Gulf, just a few short years ago.

How different is it going to be in 20 years time? How does one develop the appropriate level of skill and training, and ensure that that training and skill level will transfer to 25 years down the track, when a young lieutenant will be approaching a rank of lieutenant colonel or higher?

In a 1987 publication, Admiral Crowe, the former Chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, made a very interesting remark that is included in part 5 of the committee's report. I think it is appropriate. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Our minds are like parachutes: they won't help much if they don't open when you need them.
That is very true, of course, in respect of a whole range of endeavours, not the least of which is this particular report.

PARA.TAB: This is a very useful and timely report. I am not going to be around in the 38th Parliament to see the likely response of the government to this report. But I can assure you, as a person who has had a very significant interest in defence—at a ministerial level and, very proudly, as a member of this committee over almost three years—that I will watch with a great deal of interest the way in which the government responds to this report.

We all know that, when reports are tabled, it is an absolute miracle if every single recommendation is accepted, but I would be very surprised and disappointed if all of the recommendations were not treated seriously and thoroughly examined, because an important issue faces defence planners and governments in preparing the military after next.

I hope the work of this committee will at least ensure that, in the government response, we do get it right, and we continue the tradition of highly trained officers who are able to be diverse in transferring their training and skills to a whole range of wartime and civilian activities. I hope that great tradition continues in whatever form of officer education is accepted by the government in the years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the members before me, I think that this report of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is a very important report. In fact, I agree entirely with what the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) said. It is indeed—to use his phrase—`a landmark report'.

PARA.TAB: Without wanting to be too extreme about it, I think it is a landmark report and that would not have been possible without a great team effort. That team effort has a number of dimensions, first of all from members and senators, as the previous speakers have mentioned. I would like to take the opportunity to pay tribute to the previous chairman of the joint committee, former Senator Loosley, who drove a number of issues. I also pay tribute to the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price)—who has just walked into the Main Committee room—both as the chairman of the defence subcommittee of the joint committee and now as chairman of the joint committee.

I would also like to pay tribute to the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) as the present chairman of the defence subcommittee. And without wanting to draw too much attention to individual members of the committee, while the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), as always, was not very forward in extolling his virtues, I think both the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the member for Calare, with their ministerial experience, played a large part in the consolidation of this report.

As the two speakers before me have indicated, it would not have been possible without the team effort of the secretariat. In particular, I take the opportunity to pay tribute to Gillian Gould, who is away from the parliament at the moment at the Joint Services Staff College. I am sure she will come back—maybe not quite as refreshed, but perhaps with a new perspective on some issues. We look forward to having her back. I also pay tribute to Matthew Mason-Cox, who filled in at very short notice to complete the report for Gillian; to Wing Commander Ken Given, who has gone off to bigger and better things but whose assistance was valued by all members of the committee; and, finally, to Joanne Towner, the secretary of the present joint committee.

The report would also not have been possible without the team effort by the Australian Defence Force. I think we had the full support of the Defence Force at all rank levels. There was a very `no warts' approach and people were very open about what we were doing. I pay tribute to General John Baker, and his officers and other ranks who were involved—and there were some other ranks involved in behind-the-scenes comments on this. When the honourable member for Chifley tabled this report, there were two points he made which I think we should record once again in Hansard and with which I agree.

He said that the ADF merits commendation for its commitment to officer professional education and development, that it is second to none—and I would agree entirely with that—and that the high quality of the officer corps is a product of the individuals who are in it and the commitment to professional development, education and military training. He went on to say that the ADF is rightly proud of its traditions, but should not be frightened of creating new ones. I will come back to that point.

Finally, the report was a team effort involving a series of academics, who appeared before the committee in private and public hearings, and a number of retired people, such as Air Marshall Ray Funnell from the Australian College of Defence and Strategic Studies and others. In particular, I would like to pay tribute to the significant contribution, albeit a relatively short one, of Dr Cathy Downes. I have to say that I think the title of this particular report, Officer education: The military after next, was driven in very large part by the contribution by Dr Downes when she gave evidence to the committee—in private, I think—and made the point I would agree with entirely: that we need to take a quantum jump in a lot of these things and to be very open about a lot of the issues. Therefore, I think it was very appropriate that in this report we should address `the military after next' rather than just the next military.

As the honourable member for Calare has indicated, I spent a lot of time in uniform before I came into this place—over three decades. Some might say that that has inhibited my ability to look at the sorts of issues that are raised in this report. I would like to think that that experience—supplemented by 7 1/2, going on eight years in this parliament—has provided me with another perspective to that experience. I would like to think that that has given me a more balanced view and an ability to look at some of these issues no longer as somebody wearing a uniform, but as somebody who is able—more objectively, perhaps—to look at some of the very important issues that were raised in the context of this report.

I agree with much of what is in the report. However, I have to say that I fundamentally disagree with some of it. That might sound a bit strange, because I put my signature to this report without a dissenting view. I should explain that the reason I did that was that I was given, as a result of some discussions with the honourable member for Chifley as chairman, the ability to publicly and privately disagree with some of these issues without going to the extreme measure—and I think it is an extreme measure—of including a dissenting view in a report of this nature.

That is not to say that I am criticising Senator Margetts in terms of her dissenting report.
