I might disagree with her comments—and, indeed, I do disagree with some of what she has said, although I have to agree with her comments about more emphasis being needed in the human rights area. I do not agree with her comments that regional engagement, and regional engagement in terms of the training of officers from overseas, is counterproductive to our strategic effort. I think that is false, although I accept her right to make those comments.

As I said before, I think this is a very valuable report. It is a major report. It is a landmark report. It contains 23 recommendations, 13 of which I have very little difficulty with. With regard to the balance and, in particular, recommendation 14 on the Australian Defence Force Academy, I have already made it quite clear in the main chamber, and publicly when the report was tabled, that I cannot agree with that particular recommendation at this point in time. As a result, some of the other recommendations that flow from a recommendation that the Australian Defence Force Academy concept should be discontinued would not sit easily if recommendation 14 were not accepted.

I am glad that the honourable member for Chifley is here in the Main Committee room because, as he knows, we have disagreed—and he and I will continue to disagree—on this. I think some of the remarks he made in the House and in tabling the report and, consequently, in public were counterproductive. In particular, I think his view that the ADFA concept is a stillborn concept is false. In hindsight, he might also regret the terminology that he used in terms of the nunnery. I know that the honourable member for Calare, in his contribution a moment ago, used a slight variation of that, referring to it as a seminary. I do not agree with either of those comments and I will refer to that in a little more detail in a moment.

I also do not agree with the honourable member for Chifley that ADFA creates an elite. It creates a different grouping, but it does not necessarily create an elite. Finally, my disagreement with him in particular, and with the report in general, would be that budgetary implications seem to drive what is in the report. Indeed, I do not think that the budgetary figures add up to the actual recommendations that are made.

Again I agree with the honourable member for Chifley that the ADF must have, and continue to have, pride in its tradition. None of us, both inside and outside the ADF and in this parliament in particular, should in any way worry too much about new challenges. My personal view is that we should not have change for change's sake but if there is a demonstrable need then let us have it. In a large part of this report I agree with the need for those changes.

On the particular recommendation on the Defence Force Academy, I just have to point out to the honourable member for Chifley that the Defence Force Academy has not yet got a graduate who has reached the rank of major or equivalent. It only really started in l986 and, whilst perhaps I am rather conservative in some of my views, I would have to say, and I would hope that a lot of people would agree with me, that nine or 10 years is not really enough to prove or disprove the system that exists at the Defence Force Academy. As a result of that, I cannot agree to recommendation 14 and a number that flow from that—the centralisation of other colleges on the existing campus of the Defence Force Academy—at this point in time. That said, I think that everything in there needs to be studied.

What does worry me, however, is some sort of implication within the report that the whole issue is being driven ideologically. I say this with deep respect for the honourable member for Chifley, with whom I have a very good working relationship, but there seems to be running through this report a basic misunderstanding about the significance of rank. There seems to be some sort of ideological hang-up about a move towards a defence force which is a public service in uniform. I hope—it is not in this report but in another report, which is being taken at the moment within the Department of Defence, arising from what is termed the Glenn review—we will not see a situation where we will find the Defence Force really degenerating into a situation where it becomes a public service in uniform. Rank is not about elitism; rank is all about performance and experience. Within the defence force, rank goes hand in glove with experience, and you cannot replace experience overnight.

I will just make one or two final comments. What is in this report and what has been said publicly about the Defence Force Academy concept has generated some concern amongst the existing students, the existing staff and, importantly, potential students. However, I think it is a very good report and it merits serious consideration at ministerial level. I think some of the recommendations can be implemented without partisan debate. Others will have to be looked at very carefully. I commend most heartily this report to the parliament. I hope that the ministers and the Department of Defence will review all aspects of the report very carefully and that a large number of the recommendations will be agreed to and implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Firstly, I want to pick up some of the themes that have already been raised. I would like to thank members for their kind remarks about my contribution but, as the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) points out, this report does reflect teamwork and there have been improvements to the report that the committee as a whole and individuals can take a great deal of credit for.

PARA.TAB: I have had the pleasure of working with the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) on employment, education and training and now on defence. He is the sort of bloke who does not say a lot, but when he does people listen. He has been a bit of a bell wether for me because, when the honourable member for Isaacs says he is worried about something, I know that I have got a serious problem. He is someone whom I hold in high esteem. As the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) pointed out, all members of the committee take a great deal of pride in the committee and in the way it operates. We take pride in the fact that some committee members have been former portfolio ministers, and that we have people like the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who has a proud record of having served in uniform in the navy, and others who have performed under national service—for instance, the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson). The current chairman of the subcommittee has served in wartime—in the merchant navy, I think.

These people bring strong and bipartisan views, and a concern for the ADF. In some ways, one of the problems of the subcommittees is that we are not critical enough: we are very strongly supporting. To reiterate, this is a good report. It reflects the best traditions of parliamentary committees; it reflects the good work performed by the defence subcommittee.

I want to clear up a couple of things. Firstly, I mention the idea that the report is ideologically driven and that the committee wants a public service in uniform. I do not think that is my position at all. We need to look at some very important reports. The Glenn review has been mentioned and the government is currently considering this. Army 21 is another report and also the Noble manpower study. These reports are very significant and really point out that the ADF cannot ignore what is happening out there in civilian employment. Whilst the ADF will always lag, and properly so, it cannot lag too far behind. Therefore, we have got to be much more flexible about part-time employment in the ADF; we must not penalise people who move from full-time to part-time, or vice versa, which we currently do.

Interestingly enough, the ADF is to be congratulated for having female officers coming through—probably more than most. If we are to recoup some of that investment, not only do we have to allow them to fluctuate between full-time and part-time employment but also we have to allow them to opt out for periods without suffering gross penalties. In that sense, we need to move with the times. This is the theme of the honourable member for Groom and I have no difficulty about pleading guilty to that. Over the next five years, I think we will see some rather dramatic changes.

The honourable member for Groom also said that this report was being driven by budgetary considerations. I am on the public record in a number of places as saying that the cost of ADFA is a third order priority as far as I am concerned. It is also a baseball bat because ordinary people outside will not understand that over $400,000 has to be spent before the army produces an officer to go to his first unit, and the ADFA component of that is $308,000—a huge amount of money.

I recall stating the very same analogy to a very senior officer, and he said, `Do not be too proud. Make sure when you are in the dugout that you have the baseball bat close by.' Even if we can afford to sustain this cost over the next couple of years, I just do not believe this cost is sustainable into the next century. The pressure on the defence dollar is going to be great even if, under the five-year budget, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) sees a slight increase coming in years 3, 4 and 5. The pressures are going to be enormous.

All of us in the defence subcommittee want to ensure that the ADF preserves its capability no matter who is in government. We want to ensure that there are no cuts or changes to the ADF that interfere with its capability. It is for that reason that you have to apply what are the standard defence concepts, value for money and acceptable premiums. If you are looking into the future, if you are looking into the military after next, you cannot sustain it.
The presentation of the report provides a good opportunity to clear up some confusion. One of the themes in this report is jointery. I am surprised at the diffident definitions and concepts around.

For what it is worth, I want to put down what I thought jointery was all about. Basically it is about three things. Firstly, it provides informal networks. In other words, as a class or a cohort go through there are inevitable informal links that people make across the three services that stand them in good stead in their future careers. The second thing is that jointery is not just an aspect of sitting down together and forming a class; it is ensuring that people understand, appreciate and are knowledgeable about the different functions and roles that the different services perform. This is important for the officers in their careers. Last, but not least, a jointery ought to facilitate joint operations—in other words, with the contacts and with the knowledge to make it far smoother and more effective when they are in a joint operation. That is what I think jointery is all about. This report is stating that it is really good, that ADFA pioneered this at the earliest stages of an officer's career and we want to continue on with it.

On the scholarship side, one of the things that has not been understood is that people awarded a scholarship would still be eligible to collect Austudy if they met all the other conditions. They would have their scholarship money plus Austudy, which is doing very nicely, if I might say so.

The other argument that has been put to me that really drives me nuts is the idea that, because we have mentioned that the labour market for graduates has changed dramatically since the 1970s and the 1980s and mentioned that there is an oversupply of graduates, somehow the committee is proposing that we troll through unemployed graduates asking them if they would like a military career. Nothing could be further from the truth. What we are doing with the scholarship scheme is identifying people who are starting their undergraduate course, offering them a scholarship, making sure that they progress, and at the end of the day making a final selection.

The other point is that the scholarship scheme is a sort of free ride. I must say that one of the important contributions of the member for New England (Mr Sinclair) was to come up with the suggestion that is adopted in the report that there needs to be a period of basic training—not great but basic training—before people start the scholarship. In that way there is a loose connection throughout the scholarship of military training so that it is not just a free ride: there is some quid pro quo in it. I believe the scholarship scheme will work.

It has been suggested to me that maybe we need to start by having a trial scheme on the scholarship. That is fair enough, and I have no difficulty with that. I think it will work in spades whilst ADFA continues; but, at the end of the day, my position fundamentally is that ADFA must go.

The honourable member for Groom was picking me up on some of the language I have used, and that is fair enough. I want to make the point that, in keeping with the way the committee operates, I avoided the temptation to be partisan about ADFA and to concentrate on the controversy that surrounded its establishment. I failed to pick up on all the juicy bits about ADFA—for example, the history of bastardisation and the issue of sexual harassment. I have put that to one side, as the committee has done, and have concentrated on all the positives, and there are plenty of positives about ADFA.

By adopting such an approach in debate, you make it more difficult to give force to your arguments. If you are presenting a simple and clear message that ADFA is all bad, that is much more easily understood out there in voter land; but that is not something that I would do. That approach is dishonest and it is not even consistent with my own views. ADFA has been good. It was a bold step to set it up; it guaranteed a supply of university undergraduates and it introduced jointery. Today, I am still very proud of what ADFA is turning out. I am looking forward very much to going to my first passing out parade next month.

People who have been hurt by what has been said about ADFA ought to understand that the committee is saying that, in the context of the military after next, looking to the year 2000, it feels that these changes are absolutely necessary. After all, about $100 million out of a $200 million budget is spent on ADFA. For 1,000 undergraduates, we spend $100 million, and for the other 11,000 officers in professional development we are spending $100 million.

It is interesting that other important changes recommended in the report have, in a sense, slipped by almost without comment in the public arena, yet I believe they are fundamental and very important. For my own part, I believe the recommendations in this report facilitate the notion that regular officers, full-time officers and reserve officers should be undertaking the same courses together in the same institutions. This is a very big step for our part-time army reserve. There are difficulties with it, as we were told last night; but, again, these are very solvable.

To wind up, I would like to again acknowledge that the production of this report was a team effort. I see that the right honourable member for New England is about to speak, and I must say that it was a privilege to work with him as deputy chairman of the subcommittee. I also acknowledge the generosity of the incoming chairman, the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace), in allowing me to take this report through to the chairman's draft stage, although at that point I was no longer chairman of the subcommittee. I believe that this report will stand the test of time. I really hope not only that it provokes the ADF but also that it is implemented by them. I sincerely hope that they look at the military skills side, which was not part of our terms of reference but which they are most suitably placed to review, and that they make sure that the two things are in sync. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a few words to the debate on the report of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade entitled Officer education: the military after next. In doing so, I commend the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who preceded me in the debate, for his chairing of the subcommittee and for his participation in the deliberations which led to the presentation of the report. Indeed, thanks are due to each of the members of the committee; to the staff of the committee; to the incoming chair, the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace); and to those from the services who gave evidence to us and who really enabled the preparation of the report.

PARA.TAB: Quite apart from the recommendations, those interested in officer education and in the basis of the development of the structure of the Australian Defence Force will find that there is a lot of information in this report which is of great value. A report of this sort provides a factual groundwork on which people looking at aspects of officer education can make conclusions and form their own views.

There is no doubt that the product of the officer training establishments now operating for the Australian Defence Force is quite outstanding. One only needs to look at the incredible record of young graduates, for example, taking their part professionally in various peacekeeping forces in each of the three services. That is a role which is not specifically within the designated task of the Australian Defence Force and yet they have performed it with exceptional ability. Australia is very fortunate indeed in the quality of the young men and women who today hold commissioned rank in the services.

That does not mean that all of them are of equal calibre, nor does it necessarily mean that those who are promoted to senior officer rank were necessarily the cream of the crop at graduation. Part of the problem that we have as parliamentarians in assessing officer education is looking at why some people leave the services after having had a great deal of time and effort spent on their training and development—some in formal courses, some in the field—and in professional skills and disciplines.

One suspects that many of those who leave could very easily and very capably have filled high office in the services, yet they leave and contribute to the wider community instead. The problem of retention and the reasons why some leave and some stay is at least as important an issue as the training. We should not lose the enormous amount of experience that is inevitably acquired through the functions that they fill.

Another aspect of the development of the professional corps is that more and more service personnel are becoming specialised. In days gone by it was true that you could be a generalist and perhaps at the end of the run be seen as being able to perform any role with as much ability as somebody who had been trained in the task, with odd exceptions in particular fields like engineering, science and some other disciplines.

Today, people are becoming specialists more and more. For pilots and those with particular skills there has always been a requirement to be trained, but I remember in the air force that we were all general duties pilots. When you are one of those you really are considered to be able to do anything. I must admit that I do not know that that necessarily followed, but it is the way the disciplines of the past were applied. It concerns me that we look at the requirement in terms of officer training. I want to talk in this general way before I look at the report because I think that is important.

The fact that aspects of the report are unanimously presented does not mean that we all had the same view. It means that we felt that it was better to try and ensure that before the officer training program is accepted we come to some general consensus as to where it should go. I must admit that I have views on each of the levels of officer education, some of which are not necessarily in accord with this report. I want to speak briefly about each of them because I think they are very important.

I shall begin with the initial entry. There are a range of ways by which young men and women at this stage receive their training as officers. A remark has stuck in my mind that was made during our public hearings by the then commandant of Duntroon. I am sure it applied not only to the army but equally to all the services. He said that after six months those who were ADFA and those who were direct entry cadets really could not be distinguished one from the other. It interested me that, among the cadets at Duntroon, some had come from the ranks—in other words, were experienced as ordinary soldiers before they came in as cadets, some in peacekeeping commitments—while others had served at ADFA and had the benefits of a university type of education. They had come from considerably diverse backgrounds and yet the commandant said that after six months he could not distinguish between them. It concerns me therefore to look at recommendation 11, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the ADF conduct a feasibility study into the establishment of a tri-Service pre-commissioning college with appropriate single Service elements to replace the existing single-Service pre-commissioning colleges.

Because the service is becoming more specialised, as I suggested a few minutes ago, I have little doubt that in each of the services an opportunity must be provided to learn the trade, if you like, of that particular service.

PARA.TAB: I have some doubts about the capacity to have a triservice pre-commissioning college, other than to the degree to which we look at where we go with ADFA. In our recommendations regarding ADFA, I will pick up—and I am not going to have time to do it—the fact that I think there is a reason to have triservice training in lieu of ADFA. The training that is provided separately now in each of the single service colleges is outstanding, and I do not believe that that can easily be replaced.

ADFA has always worried me because I grew up in a generation immediately after World War II when so many from the services were at the university and when some who had been very senior officers in the Australian Defence Force were doing their university education. I have felt that there is a real advantage in opportunities being given for people who are going into the Defence Force to mingle in the wider community, within the various disciplines that are available at universities.

There are several reasons for that. One is that the initial education can be done in their own state. In other words, people who come from Western Australia, the Northern Territory, Queensland or wherever are able to do part of their tertiary education in a university in their own state and then come together to get their professional education. While ADFA has produced some outstanding young men and women graduates, given the cost of ADFA and the fact that those young men and women are growing up in an atmosphere removed from other undergraduates and that the commandant of Duntroon has said that, after six months, he cannot distinguish between them, I do not believe that the maintenance of ADFA in its present form is justified.

For that reason I am one of those who believe quite strongly that it would be far better to adopt a scholarship scheme, and recommendations have been provided in the report. Whether that is the right way to go, I believe, is more a matter for the professionals. We have suggested in recommendation 16 that if there is a sponsorship scheme the students should go through a pre-entry introduction to the services to learn how to be service personnel before they go to university. Throughout their university education they would remain attached to a training establishment, both triservice and single service, so that by the time they have finished their university education they have achieved approximately 12 months of military training.

After they have graduated they would need to go back for triservice and single service training. Time for that has been recommended to be set aside but the length of that training needs to be assessed, and that is, as I say, a matter for the professionals. By being educated in the wider world they are going to gain access to those who will become graduates in all sorts of careers and their access as senior service personnel will be much wider than it would be by being graduates of ADFA.

Whether it means they are going to be any better officers at the end of the run is a matter of judgment. I was minister at the time that ADFA was established. I had a great deal of input in the cabinet discussions when John Gorton first raised the question. It was a matter that John Gorton as minister for defence, Malcolm Fraser as minister for defence and Jim Killen as minister for defence raised; it was not just Lance Barnard and the Labor Party who thought about where we should go in officer education. This concept has had a long evolution, and I am one of those who feels that the ADFA concept is not worth the high expense that it needs in its present form, and therefore it is worth looking at this alternative.

Because we have made recommendations, I would hope that they are not dismissed and are looked at very carefully. I think that it is essential that we do not wait, although I know my colleague the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) would like us to wait a little longer before we make a judgment on ADFA. In my view, there really has to be an assessment made of this alternative. I think that there are ways by which you could train officers to the same degree as you are training them through ADFA by sending them out to the wider university. I think you would actually produce better officers as a result of it, and I believe that recommendation needs to be adopted.

We made some recommendations about setting up a single staff college. I think that is the way to go. Our recommendation 13 would fix that up and should allow at the same time the individual requirements of each of the services. They do vary in the duration of their courses, but with each of those senior colleges—the senior staff colleges of each service, the Joint Services Staff College and the Australian College of Defence and Strategic Studies—I have real worries. I do not believe the people who are going are necessarily the people who should go; often they are the people who are available to go. The more that funds are restricted to the services, the more likely that is to be so.

It worries me that the time taken out of a senior officer's career is such that it would be very difficult indeed for all those who should go to be given vacancies. I believe, for example, that it is quite impossible for a senior officer who is in a highly responsible job to take the 12 months that the Australian College of Defence and Strategic Studies presently requires. I think it would be far better to have many short courses, to allow more personnel to go, and to make sure that everybody goes to them. Although we have made recommendations with the Joint Services Staff College, we have made none about the ACDSS. I feel quite strongly that the time for both is in fact too long for people who need to go, and therefore you are not getting some of the people who should go to those courses.

We also have to look at ways by which people can take those courses externally on the theoretical side so that they can spend perhaps less time together in a physical sense. I think that we do need to look at how management in the commercial world and in the professional world operates. Every profession has courses that are available to senior practitioners, and not every one of them takes 12 months, because most people cannot afford it. I worry that, because of the way these courses are structured, we are precluding people who should go to them.

While I go along with the recommendation of this report, and endorse much of what has been said by my colleagues, each one of us has a different emphasis and a different background, which means we perhaps come to different conclusions. There are a number of these recommendations where I think some of us have doubts. At the same time, I do not believe that the Defence Force should just cast aside the recommendation on ADFA, and I think they need to look very carefully at the comments we have made at each of the levels of officer training.

The essential requirement for the future is that the quality of today's officers is at least maintained in any change, and that we try to ensure that every officer of the Australian Defence Force is given an opportunity to enter those senior colleges. If they do not, and people are promoted although they have not been to them, that rather suggests that the courses themselves have a deficiency. I think, therefore, at each level, officer training needs to be reviewed not only as we have done as politicians but also within the Defence Force, and I would hope it is something that each of us can look at again in the new parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to speak to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Officer education: The military after next. I preface my remarks with some general comments about defence and the way we should be looking forward when we talk about the military after next, and, more importantly, what that means in terms of where the nation is going.

PARA.TAB: We ought to start from a fundamental point with an observation that, until we have a government that runs the economy and reforms the economy so that it can start to go forward, we will always have a problem in providing the necessary resources to provide effective security for Australians. That is a fairly fundamental point which should preface remarks on this report.

The other point that I make in prefacing my remarks is that we need to improve our approach to defence issues and, in particular, we need to bring more debate before the Australian people. We need to bring it to the attention of the general public so that they become more involved and take a greater interest, and then, we hope, demand greater accountability and performance in the maintenance of the proper defence of this nation. Thus I make the point about the importance of a reformed economy, one that actually moves forward, which will place us in a position to be able to afford the sort of defence capability necessary to ensure the future of Australia as a free nation.

This comes right back to the question of political leadership. At times, the current government has been lacking in giving defence the sort of priority it should have. Clearly, in some ways, the defence forces themselves have something to answer for in the whole question of public relations. Too often, I believe, the public relations of the defence forces have tended to cover up some of the deficiencies of the government, keeping the Minister for Defence himself out of the firing line rather than highlighting what the wider public ought to be fully informed on.

It is also important that, in informing the Australian public, we also ensure that Australian industry is fully aware of the importance of defence. I know that some sections are very good when it comes to supporting our reservists, but I think that many are not fully aware of the importance of an adequate defence force. They ought to be made aware of that, not only in terms of the national interest but in terms of what it could mean for their own particular industries.

At the same time, some of our tertiary institutions have not improved the education and understanding of the general public and, in particular, they have not analysed why some of our neighbours seem to spend a lot more time emphasising national self-reliance—not only our neighbours but many other countries in the world—and why they put such an importance on these issues when in Australia we seem to be a little complacent and believe that we can put it off and not worry about it today because it will not be a problem in the foreseeable future.

These are the sorts of issues that should have a higher profile in the national debate. An awareness of their importance would then back up some of the efforts of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, when they do their grand tours of the world deluding themselves that Australia is more influential than it really is. One of the reasons that we do not carry the sort of influence that we should is, as I have mentioned, because we need to improve our economic performance. By doing that we can demonstrate that we have a real defence capability that matches the rhetoric that too often both the Leader of the Government (Mr Beazley) and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, seem to indulge in.

That is really the starting point. It is backed up by the very real concerns that I think many Australians would have had on reading the comments earlier this week of the recently retired Chief of the General Staff, General Grey, when he made the point that he did not believe Australia could sustain a prolonged defence of the nation. That was a very disturbing comment from an eminent person who is highly regarded and is certainly someone who would not make those comments lightly. I would have thought that they should have been given far greater prominence and had far more response from the government than appears to have occurred so far.

When we turn to the report itself and one of the central issues—the closure of undergraduate training of officers at ADFA—it is very important that we ensure that, if the government chooses to go down this path, it is extremely well managed. This is going to be one of the critical issues. If it is not well managed, there could be some serious long-term ramifications of making what would be a fairly major change in the approach to officer training.

As part of that change, we obviously have to look very closely at the whole question of scholarships. I think that should be trialled as a way of ensuring that we do not run into the problem that was raised by one of the very senior staff at ADFA, Dr Hugh Smith, when he pointed out that his main concern—if we go down this path—was that the ADF would not be able to attract numbers of suitable graduates to fill its officer ranks. That is a serious comment and something that we should be very mindful of.

There are a number of other comments that might back up the move down this line. Interestingly, I found in talking to a friend of mine who is an officer in the reserve that he felt very concerned about some of the attitudes of ADFA graduates. Probably one of the more telling comments he made to me was that it seemed that in the army there was a feeling that they have difficulty thinking laterally. That is just one piece of anecdotal evidence, but I have a high regard for this person and therefore would listen to his comments quite seriously.

The other point to emphasise that is running through some of the recommendations and that I think shows there is still need for improvement in the whole question of officer training was highlighted with the experience of the Kangaroo 95 exercise this year. Despite the significant commonality of the staff colleges, there is still the opportunity for separate training. But the K95 experience showed that there is a weakness of command and control. If Australia is going to be put in a position where our defence forces are going to have to take the leading role, this weakness is going to have to be addressed. Considering that this is not something that is particularly new—it has been recognised for some years now—there is growing concern that it still does not seem to have been resolved. Therefore, I think this point has to be put on the priority list and, in training our officers, we have to make sure that we can get past that problem.

The other point that could be made about the current officer training is that it is a very structured system. In relation to the training through their careers, there is a feeling that, if officers miss the opportunity as they move up the ranks to get additional training, they will miss out because there is a fairly narrow opportunity as they go through their careers of getting that additional training and getting the opportunity to get promotions as a result.

Clearly this is an issue which defence forces are still going to have to look at. As I say, because training can be very structured, there is a feeling amongst some that there is not enough encouragement of officers to take their own initiative, and there are times when those who are natural self-starters will feel that their ability to take that initiative is being inhibited. There is a strong feeling that the current system is working very much against those people. Even given the importance of the way defence has to operate, nonetheless we should be giving more encouragement to those future leaders.

Another point that must be emphasised in the whole question of training in The military after next is the importance of developing links within the civilian community and, importantly, within industry. Given that one of the areas that we are going to have to look at in defending the nation is what might be called New-Age threats—I am talking about things such as information warfare—it is terribly important that the leaders of the military do have that capability through the fact that they have a wide range of contacts in industries that either could be threatened or could assist in the defence of this nation.

It also must be emphasised that in looking forward we must not overlook some of the present demands that are being made on the military, in particular the very important and significant role that members of the Australian Defence Force are playing in peacekeeping around the world. They are acquitting themselves in such a way that all Australians could be very proud. It is important that we do not overlook that role because, unfortunately, it looks like being a demand that is going to be made on nations such as Australia for the foreseeable future. I would just highlight again that it is going to be a major challenge to make the transition towards some of these recommendations if they are followed up.

I would like now just to comment on two other aspects. Firstly, I think that it was disappointing to see the dissenting report of Senator Margetts. I think that it shows that particular senator is losing her credibility by continuing to write these dissenting reports which really are pushing another barrow which is not directly related to the main thrust of this report. Secondly, I would also like to put on record my thanks to the staff. I mention particularly Gillian Gould, who put tireless effort into working for the committee, and Matthew Mason-Cox, who then took over from Gillian in July; and I thank Peter McLay and Wing Commander Ken Given for their support. The committee greatly appreciated the work that was done which helped to bring this report up to the sort of standard that is expected from the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

I conclude with those remarks and say that I too support the thrust of this report. I think that it offers some very challenging recommendations for the next government and I believe it will be one of the major issues that will have to be considered in the future of our defence forces.
Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned.
Debated resumed from 26 October, on motion by Mr Price:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of us have been conscious of the very dramatic changes that have occurred in our region and have been generally impressed by them. It does not mean that we have necessarily seen each country as falling into the one mould, nor does it mean that we have endorsed all—or, for that matter, any—particular policy of any of the countries in our region. ASEAN has grown and become a very significant regional organisation and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has just returned now from a meeting of APEC, another association which is bringing, in trade terms, a group of countries in this region together, with perhaps a more commercial bent.

PARA.TAB: Each one of these forums is really intent on trying to open up the opportunities for dialogue and for individual progress; as a result, living standards generally have risen. We in Australia are conscious that comparatively our standards seem to be falling, particularly when one measures them by economic criteria, against the standards in countries such as Singapore, or even Malaysia or Hong Kong, and the new tigers, Japan and Taiwan.

Having said that, within our region, a number of countries are still quite properly concerned about what we see as human rights. I met a parliamentary delegation from Thailand last week and they said that, as Australians, we have to accept that they do not see everything as we do. They are different ethnically and religiously and they have different attitudes from us. As a result, we need to be very careful about what issues we lecture them on because they are going through a different stage of evolution and their standards and attitudes are different.

While that might well be so, this report from the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade, Human rights and progress towards democracy in Burma, is not intended in any way to be prejudicial against the individual judgments that the government might make. For the purpose of this report, we have used the name Burma, or Myanmar, as some might call it. We have attempted to identify the areas where we see Burma falling behind other countries in this region. These are areas where we believe the State Law and Order Council, or SLORC, is prejudicing reasonable development. It is not for us to determine the form of government or the leaders who will set the policies of the country. The policies of SLORC seem to deny significantly the rights of individuals in that country. The report itself follows a reference from the Senate. In that reference, we were requested to inquire into and report on the human rights situation and the lack of progress towards democracy in Burma (Myanmar).

This report is the product of that inquiry and, in opening, I would like to pay particular credit to the former chairman of the committee, Mr Stephen Loosley. At that time he was a senator and he led the early part of the inquiry. More recently, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) assumed that role after Mr Loosley retired from the Senate. The real praise and thanks must go to Margaret Swieringa, who, within the subcommittee secretariat, has put an inordinate amount of time and effort into the preparation of this paper, which is a very good analysis of the situation.

I open by saying that I would hope that those in Burma, and particularly the members of the State Law and Order Restoration Council, do not dismiss the report because it comes from Australia. The concerns that we have here are very genuine; they are very valid; and they are totally bipartisan. While we all feel very strongly about these issues—and we do not necessarily have the same view—when it comes to human rights and the development of democracy in Myanmar, there is no doubt that we are all concerned that progress seems to have stalled.

Therefore, I want to pick up some of the issues surrounding our recommendations and some of the conclusions we reached. Firstly, it is worth noting that we have defined human rights in chapter 2 of the report. We have done that because human rights is something that is seen differently in different countries—and I have mentioned my friends from the parliamentary delegation from Thailand.

It might well be that in the interpretation of human rights there is some room for variation, but our reason for putting in this definition is to make it clear that we are not talking about matters that pertain to government, or forms of election or even the processes of administration. We say that human rights are the rights we have—that is, each of us as humans—because we are human beings; they do not belong to us because we are of any particular ethnic origin, be it Australian, Burmese, Chinese or American. As they belong to us as human beings, they cannot be modified or coloured by nationality, historical experience or culture. It is very important that we understand that. The record of evidence that led to this report produced some absolutely horrific stories of the way in which individuals were treated within Burma (Myanmar).

It was appalling to hear of conscripted labour, of the fate of some of those who are minority peoples in Burma, of the extent to which there was trade in women and children across the borders, and of the extent to which they were exploited with no opportunity of any individual resistance. It is appalling to think of the physical punishment, the torture, the deprivation that was applied to individuals. While we have not catalogued it, there is reference to some individual instances. Some of the evidence we have received is absolutely horrific.

The drug trade is very much part of it. It has flourished in northern Burma for many years. Unfortunately in the Shan state major Chinese narcotics traffickers have become involved. There is traffic across the border into Thailand, and there has been not only a trade in humans but a trade in drugs. The price paid for drugs means that it has become by far the most profitable form of commerce. War lords develop their own individual empires around the drug trade. It is a situation which leads us, as members of the Australian parliament, to have great concerns as to where Burma is heading.

I was very pleased to see that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, has decided that he is now not going to visit Burma, although it had been announced that he intended to do so. There is always a difficulty in knowing how far you can, by not maintaining or having a dialogue, persuade others to your point of view. I have always been of the view that we need to maintain to the maximum, dialogue with countries which have different attitudes from ours. For that reason I am very strongly in favour of our maintaining senior diplomatic representation in Rangoon. It is essential that we have dialogue.

It is also essential that the government of Burma, the SLORC regime, ensures that visitors are allowed free movement within that country. It is important that people are allowed to go up country, to go to the Thai border, to see the refugees, or to talk to those who have been returned from neighbouring countries, so that there can be assistance given. At the moment the assistance given on the Thai side of the border largely stops at the border. The non-government organisations are inhibited in the work that they can do within Burma. There is a problem in trying to ensure that there is free access for those who would help the underprivileged and the persecuted within Burma. It is absolutely essential that they be given access.

For those of us in Australia, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi has symbolised our concern. I know of her through the award of the Nobel prize, and I have heard her broadcasts. From the little I have heard of her, I have been incredibly impressed. Anyone who has heard her cool, rational argument, registering the fact that having been elected as Prime Minister she was held under house arrest, and was not permitted to engage in normal political activity, has to be impressed by the way in which this woman has been able to hold her head high and still muster forces—not in the military sense, but in the democratic sense—against a regime which engages in abuses which we condemn.

To hear that only this day there seems to be a new wave of persecution against her concerns me greatly. I do not believe it is going to help Burma. It is not going to help the government, or the people of Burma, if the SLORC insist on preventing Daw Aung San Suu Kyi participating in political processes, nor is it going to assist in the transfer to democracy.

It is essential that the SLORC regime registers the fact that nations like Australia believe that assistance from the World Bank or the Asian Development Bank and international aid should not be permitted if the regime prevents normal democratic processes. For my money, it is a great pity because, when this happens, it is not the members of the regime who suffer; it is the ordinary men, women and children. In Burma, the ordinary men, women and children badly need help.

Burma is, of course, a large, strategically placed country which borders India, China, Bangladesh, Thailand and Laos. It is a country which is close to much of the cauldron of development in this region: India and China, the two largest countries in the world. There is no doubt that numerically, in population terms, Burma is a country with enormous natural resources, both human and physical.

It is of interest that the former Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, visited the country, but it concerns me greatly that he did not see Daw Aung San Suu Kyi when he was there. It concerns me that he came back and reported—in a way that most of us think is very sad—that he thinks much progress has been made by SLORC and that he is very impressed with individual members of SLORC. I trust that the ordinary people of Burma understand that the views that former Prime Minister Hawke expressed are not necessarily those of the Australian parliament. Indeed, many of us feel that there has been too little progress. It is on this very score that the recommendations in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade—which are largely directed towards bringing Burma back into the international community—are directed.

I trust that the government of Burma will not just dismiss the recommendations, but will read the recommendations and understand that they are intended to help Burma, not to hinder Burma. The recommendations are designed to help progress the people of Burma and to give to the people of Burma the same individual rights which the members of the SLORC regime seek for themselves. This is what this report is about. The report is trying to bring Burma (Myanmar) back into the international community. If, in a small way, the report can help to this end, the report will be worth while.

I commend the report to the parliament and, above all, I commend it to the members of the SLORC regime. I trust that the process of democracy and the evolution of attitudes towards individuals will progress as a result of the report for, sadly, these matters seem very backward at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very appropriate day to be debating this report, Human rights and progress towards democracy in Burma, because, as anyone who has had a casual glance through the newspapers today and who has seen most of the leading newspapers' comments about the convention that started yesterday in Burma knows, the State Law and Order Restoration Council—the rulers—has taken its usual uncompromising, hardline view concerning the opposition in Burma. When we talk about the opposition in Burma, what one should always be aware of is that, in the elections of 1990, the opposition had a considerable win. The party, lead by Aung San Suu Kyi, actually won 392 of the 486 contested seats, but the SLORC blocked the party from taking power and, as we know, put the leader of the party under house arrest, where she remained until recently.

PARA.TAB: What we find coming out in reports in all the leading newspapers is that the SLORC is continuing its very hardline view. I quote from one newspaper, the Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: Burma's military regime refused to make any concessions to Miss Aung San Suu Kyi's pro-democracy movement at yesterday's international convention.

This convention had been described as a convention that is flawed, fixed and, in its present form, not acceptable to the people of Burma. Of the 703 delegates to that convention, the pro-democracy movement was permitted to have 97 delegates there. It is a flawed convention and it is being used by SLORC to entrench themselves, to entrench the military in power. They grab power, and they are now rewriting the constitution to ensure that the military will remain in power.

PARA.TAB: It is fairly hard, I guess, for us to understand this, and it is going to be increasingly interesting throughout this coming year—only another month and we will be in the new year—which is the Year of Tourism in Burma. Already we see it. Members of parliament and others who travel by Qantas would notice in this month's Australian Way, the magazine of Qantas, an article entitled `The land of the gold pagodas'. This presents a very sympathetic and flattering portrayal of Burma. As you thumb through other glossy magazines you get a similar picture. One I picked up in Britain a while ago was talking about a river cruise, suggesting `Let's go to Mandalay' and places like that.

There are these sympathetic articles accompanied by beautiful photographs, because it is a very beautiful country. Next year will be the Year of Tourism in Burma and people throughout the world will be enticed to visit this beautiful but tragic country. As the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) said, if tourists do go there they most certainly will not go into the border area, or where there is forced labour, where they are putting the pipeline through to Thailand, where villagers are being taken as forced labour to work on those things.

There is always a question for countries throughout the world today, as we all become more and more aware of human rights, that we should be judged by the way we treat our minorities. Rest assured that the way the minorities are treated in Burma is a matter of shame for the Burmese military regime, those entrenched colonels and other military people who have been in power there, who have grabbed power and have been illegally holding it. Far from being a paradise, unfortunately, Burma is a country where people's human rights and dignities are trampled under with jackboot ruthless authority. In Burma, increasingly, there is a trade in human misery. I was on the committee looking at this when we were told about the trade in young girls taken from the hill areas and often taken into Thailand. We all know of AIDS throughout Asia, throughout the world today. These young people are infected with this dreadful disease and then just sent back into that area. There is a trade in drugs. Quite frankly, the military, the SLORC, in Burma are trafficking in human misery, and we should have no part of that.

I make this claim, that any Australian who visits Burma, be they a former Prime Minister or be they a backpacker, especially in this coming year, is giving support for that evil, ruthless regime. That is what they are doing. The higher up you are, be you a member of parliament, be you a former Prime Minister or be you a leading business person, you are being used by the Burmese authorities exactly as the apartheid regime used those Uncle Toms—many from this parliament—who went to South Africa and were wooed and wined and dined there. They came back to this country and made speech after speech in the chamber that there was nothing wrong with the apartheid regime in South Africa—the blacks were being well treated, they were treated better than in surrounding countries, there was an efficient government in charge and things like that.

I was there when the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, gave his evidence and I was disappointed with what he said. No-one fought harder against apartheid than Mr Hawke; I will give him that. But the argument that he put was exactly the argument that has been put many times in this parliament about the apartheid regime. I say to people that this coming year, the Year of Tourism in Burma, is not the year to visit Burma. I do not think any year is the year to visit Burma—at least, not until free and democratic elections are held and the rightful party is in government. When free and democratic elections were held in 1990, there was an overwhelming vote for the pro-democracy people. It was not a vote where, as sometimes happens around the world, there was a very narrow result. It was not like the divorce vote in Ireland over the weekend where there was a minute margin—I think it came down to 7,000 votes out of a couple of million. This was an overwhelming vote for pro-democracy.

We keep hearing about the so-called Asian tigers. I tend to glance through and follow articles in the Far Eastern Economic Review and other Asian papers because I have a particular interest in Asia. I keep reading about the investment opportunities in Burma and that Burma is going to be the next country in Asia to take off. But at what price is it going to take off? Anyone who thinks that I or other speakers in this debate exaggerate should read the transcripts of evidence. Unfortunately, a lot of evidence had to be taken in camera because many of the people who spoke to us had relatives and friends in Burma, and we had to give them an undertaking that the evidence would be given in camera. What came out of that evidence was a picture of a ruthlessly frightening regime where there is no respect for human rights. I do not think that that is the way we should build an economy. We should not be investing there and most certainly we should not be visiting there.

People say, `What right has Australia to interfere in the human rights of other countries?' It is the same argument that they used about apartheid. I was surprised when this was brought down in the chamber a month or so ago that the Australia media was so interested that not one paper printed anything about it! A couple of days later, and this says something about the Australian media, a report—not nearly as thorough and as well researched as this one—was brought down in the United States and most of the papers in Australia carried extensive coverage of it. No Australian media thought the report that was brought down in this parliament worthy enough to make any comment on it at all. I think that says quite a lot about the Australian media and their lack of interest in so many issues. I suppose because various people did not write it for them they were too lazy to do their own work, to do a bit of research, go through the recommendations and see exactly what we were talking about.

Like the right honourable member for New England, I would like to pay a particular tribute to Margaret Swieringa. I serve on several committees in this parliament and I do not know anyone who brings the dedication and the expertise to this field that Margaret Swieringa does. It is a field that she has particular feel for. She has a tremendous knowledge in the whole area of human rights and she is a very competent writer. I pay a particular tribute to her for the tremendous contribution that she has made to this report.

I would like to touch on some matters concerning ILO conventions in Burma. Burma has signed these conventions but has not adhered to them. Another point is that, because there is cheap labour in Burma, the Burmese authorities are forming contracts for labourers as seafarers, and using the wages paid to Burmese seafarers to assist their foreign currency situation.

There has been a dissenting report, which is unfortunate because, in some respects, it weakens the strength of this report. When we are talking about human rights it is very difficult to criticise someone for putting in a dissenting report, and I have no personal animosity towards Senator Margetts. I like her as a person, but she has built up something of a reputation. I do not know about other committees she serves on, but with every report that comes down from the foreign affairs, defence and trade committee she feels compelled to put in a dissenting report. Often, her dissenting report indicates that she either has not followed the evidence very closely or is not really across the issues. This report is an important report, should be widely read and should have a fairly wide international readership. The very fact that Senator Margetts has seen fit to put in a dissenting report really does lessen the value of this report. That is a great pity. On every committee I am on, we always strive, during the drafting stages, to reach unanimity. Sometimes, many of us who feel strongly on issues have to compromise. We always compromise so that we will get a unanimous report. When we are going to argue—not necessarily in Australia, but in international forums—it is easier to say, `Here is a unanimous report from the Australian party, covering all aspects of political opinion in Australia.'

I commend this report. I commend it to every member of the parliament. I think every member should read it. I really do think that no Australian member of parliament, present or past, should visit Burma in this coming year—the Year of Tourism in Burma.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few brief comments on the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Human rights and progress towards democracy in Burma. I commend the comments of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), and commend the committee for this report.

PARA.TAB: I have been concerned about this issue for many years. I think the record will show that I moved the very first motion in the House in support of Aung San Suu Kyi, years ago, when she was first arrested and we had the dreadful military situation in Burma. We gained some hope from her recent release, but now we see that progress, as the member for Throsby has indicated, is still extremely slow.

Two things need to be said. Both members have referred to the issue of the indivisible nature of human rights. I have a lot to say on this matter in my new book, and I have said things about it in other speeches. We should not confuse questions of cultural diversity and differences in cultural traditions with the fact that we are one humanity and there are some fundamental human rights that are indivisible and must be sustained. That is a very important issue. As the honourable member for Throsby said, sometimes we forgot that when we were talking about South Africa in earlier times.

The reality is that human rights are endangered when any nation does the sort of things that are happening at the moment in Burma, and we cannot accept that. This parliament has condemned it in a number of ways and the report has documented a lot of the issues. It is a great report in that regard.

We must not pull away from our commitment to human rights. I am hopeful of a revolution in Burma in which Aung San Suu Kyi will eventually come, through the democratic process, to take her rightful place as the leader of this nation because, if there were to be an election tomorrow, she would be overwhelmingly endorsed.

Not only those people who love democracy but also those people who love human rights should endorse the report and should endorse whatever the Australian government can do to support those who are suffering from abuses of human rights in Burma. Also, most importantly, they should support the restoration of democracy in Burma and thereby strengthen the importance of democracy in our region.

We should not allow short-term economic interest to override the overwhelming concern with human rights. In fact, those people who pursue limited, short-term economic interests usually fall flat when dealing with such regimes because they cannot be trusted to even obey normal commercial rules, never mind anything else. Our fundamental thing here is that we ought to get behind the report, we ought to refer to it and we ought to ensure that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade are very much aware of the views of parliamentarians. We want to see action by Australia to do everything we can to push forward the cause of the restoration of democracy in Burma.
Debate (on motion by Mr Robert Brown) be adjourned.
Debated resumed from 20 November, on motion by Mr Price:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start, can I say that I think these sitting hours are stupid. I would have rather enjoyed having a bit of lunch, instead of this business of talking through lunchtime.

PARA.TAB: The report that we are about to deal with is a third from the same stable. Like all committees at the end of a parliament, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has produced a number of fairly significant publications, each of which is intended not just for domestic but for wider consumption.

In opening on the report on Australia's relationship with Thailand, I totally endorse the comments by the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). I find it quite incredible that a report of such significance as that which we have just debated on Burma is virtually ignored by the media and yet, because the United States Congress produces a report that is nowhere near as adequate, they give it a great run. A few of our journalists need to understand that we are not slaves of the USA, that we do have a bit of independence and that we do have quite a deal of work of increasingly important relevance to the Australian community emerging from this parliament. It is quite stupid that the media manages to pick up what happens in the United States Congress and forgets that the Australian parliament produces work that has an Australian emphasis, an Australian idiom and is of far more consequence for the Australian electorate than anything that they might see in some report that comes out of the United States Congress. Indeed, if we want to influence the US Congress, the best way is to let them know that the work we produce is of a higher order than theirs—it often is.

The report relates to Australia's relations with Thailand. It has been a product of fairly extensive study by the foreign affairs subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I pay tribute to Mr Laurie Ferguson, who has been the chair of that committee, for the work he has done over the years and to Patrick Regan and those who helped in the preparation of the report.

The report deals with an emphasis different from that that we have just dealt with. The report on Burma was really looking at human rights and the implications for Burma's integration into, particularly, our part of the world as a result of the regime that is currently in control there, SLORC, and the attitude it has adopted towards individuals. This one is of a different order altogether.

The Kingdom of Thailand is a very significant country. The kingdom has contributed greatly towards the formation and development of ASEAN. Thailand was a prime mover in the establishment of the Cairns Group, which was so important in the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which led to the establishment of the World Trade Organisation. Thailand has been a friend of Australia's for many years, and in World War II, tragically, many Australians lost their lives serving on the Burma-Thailand railway as prisoners of war of the Japanese.

While this report goes into the concepts of our relationship in more depth, I would be wrong if I did not mention that, following the visit of the foreign affairs subcommittee to Thailand, we referred to a number of the matters that we pick up again in this report. In particular, that early relationship, the relationship during World War II, is of tremendous consequence. We were fortunate, as a group of parliamentarians, in being able to go to Hellfire Pass. We saw where the ashes of Weary Dunlop were spread. We saw something in today's environment of what must have been absolute hell for that generation of Australians, whose life and death and service we have been commemorating in the Australia Remembers services around Australia these past 12 months.

It is important that we remember that that heritage is something that is not just a matter of attending a shrine in Australia or visiting a war grave. It is something that is living and ongoing. The important part about our relationship with Thailand is that it was tremendously important at that time. In a way, I have always felt it gave Australia a particular association with Asia—not peculiarly with Thailand but with Burma, about which we have just been talking, and of course with Singapore and Malaya. It is an ongoing part of the change from Australia being oriented to Europe to Australia being oriented to this part of the world.

Our relationship with Thailand is an ongoing one. It is not something that is just a product of Thailand being a very populous state with a rising standard of living, as one of the new tigers, as they call the country sometimes. It is a country that is said to be the land of smiles. It is a country where the monarchy has incredible stature, and we have referred to that in this report. The monarchy unites Thailand in a remarkable way. I remember that during my several visits to Thailand during the Vietnam War it was quite amazing going to Thailand and then going to other countries in Asia. The people all were united in a way that, sadly, has not been so in many of the other countries of Asia. I think that it is important to respect and understand the sensitivities of the Thai people to their monarchy, and the very high esteem in which members of the royal family are held there.

It may well not be the way that we see our monarchy. Indeed, it has been sad that some media have tended to compare our relationship with our monarchy with the relations of the Thai people with their monarchy. Not only is that an affront to the Thais but it helps to give the Thais a feeling that we do not understand them. That is unfortunate, because it is tremendously important that we understand the differences in attitudes of people in other countries. This report, we hope, will help towards improving that relationship.

The reason I have opened by talking about those issues is that I was fortunate in meeting a delegation from the foreign affairs committee of Thailand last week. There were only Senator Baden Teague and I in town, and I had quite a long session with them. They expressed reservations to me about Australia's attitude to Thailand. They spoke about newspaper comments, they spoke about media attitudes towards their monarchy and they spoke about the concern they have that we try and see them through our own eyes without understanding that they see themselves differently.

I said to them that this report is not intended for us to tell them what to do; it is more to promote an understanding in Australia of the importance of our relationship with Thailand. Thailand is a tremendously important neighbour. Unfortunately, because its language is complex and its culture is different, it tends to have been played down. In our recommendations we have picked up how important it is that we maintain training and education in the Thai language. It is not now one of the major languages taught in Australia and I understand it is extraordinarily difficult to learn. Yet I have a daughter who spent some years in Thailand and is a Thai linguist and she says that the language, once you have learnt it, is very much like any other language. It is a living language, a spoken language, and one that enables you, simply by having a facility in that language, to communicate through a wide range of areas.

We have made recommendations in our report about funding a number of institutions to ensure that there is a continued understanding of the Thai language and culture in our country. In particular, we have expressed our concern that the National Thai Studies Centre at the Australian National University should continue to be funded. It is tremendously important that we maintain opportunities to develop Thai studies and an understanding of Thai culture, not just at the ANU but around Australia at the tertiary and secondary level.

Thailand is an important country in our region. While many Thais speak English, it is not sufficient for us to go there and be totally ignorant not just of their language but of their culture. There are sensitivities which are important. For example, it was said to me that while we might regard some issues as being bad manners, such as a young man putting his feet on a table and pointing his feet at his parents, that would be a total affront to a person in Thailand. We might not see that as something unusual. Indeed, many of us in our offices and in the privacy of our homes—and some, sadly, in even more public places—adopt that posture without thinking. But, to a Thai, that is a total affront. We need to understand that they see things differently, that they do not see and feel things as we do. We would do well to remember that.

The preservation of these facilities around Australia to learn of Thai culture and to learn the Thai language is absolutely critical. I am particularly concerned that the federal government apparently is considering reducing, or eliminating altogether, the funding that is provided for the Thai language centre at the ANU. If that should be so—and we made comments about this in our earlier report—it would be a great tragedy.

It is not only in the teaching of Thai language but also in the communication between our countries that I am worried about where we go. This same delegation I saw the other day mentioned to me their concern that we are apparently intending to cut down some of the ABC funding for both television and radio in the Thai language. If that were so it would be a great tragedy because Radio Australia has provided an excellent Thai language program for a long time. I think it is essential that it be maintained.

People in those countries often have learnt English through the broadcasting services that we have provided in the past and, hopefully, can learn a little of the positive as well as the negative side of our society through television programs. We are foolish if we just want to broadcast or televise programs that might suit our culture. We are not really trying to get through to the tourists in the five-star, four-star or even three-star hotels. What we are trying to do is to ensure that they understand the Australian community, the Australian people.

There are far more benefits from having programs that run across our language, our culture, our educational emphases, our attitude to democracy and our attitude to human rights. All these things are matters that go on the ABC. If it should be that there is to be a reduction in the ABC's international services that affected our Thai services, I believe that it would be a great tragedy—not just now, but in the continuity of the relationship between our countries. I was most concerned to hear of this and hope that the recommendations we have made in this report on the maintenance of Thai language programs will be noted by the government. Even though I know funding is scarce, it is essential that the ABC be directed to maintain those outlets.

In education, we have spoken predominantly in the report about teaching Thai language and culture in Australia. I have to confess—to my chagrin—that I had not heard of the University of Mahanakorn until I went to Thailand. Because that was the case, I want to just comment briefly about it.

The Vice-Chancellor, Dr Sitthichai Pookaiyaudom, was a double graduate of the University of New South Wales and one of the most extroverted and delightful individuals anybody would find anywhere. Apart from the fact that he has a taste for malt whisky, which also endeared him to a number of us—

TALK.START.PARA: —Very sensible!

—Very sensible taste! It was really quite remarkable meeting this very Thai academic who had a very Australian idiom and approach—not just to malt whisky but to other things. Of course, the university functions in association with the University of New South Wales. I am interested in Mahanakorn because it is a private university that is providing a very high level of technical and vocational education, and it is one which is very much to be commended. I hope that, when we look at how we assist countries like Thailand, we maintain our relationship with such universities because it can help a great deal.

PARA.TAB: Time is running out. I want to talk about one other subject before I conclude, and that is the drug trade and the work being done by the Australian Federal Police and in the refugee camps on the Thai-Burma border and generally along the Thai border. Thailand has been a host country for refugees from Cambodia and Laos and it certainly is still, sadly, a host to refugees from Burma. It is terribly important that we maintain our effort to contain the drug trade. The measures that have been adopted to try and develop alternative crops are well worth while, but it is a program which needs to be ongoing. We need to coordinate our effort with the Americans, but we also need to make sure we coordinate our effort with the non-government agencies. There is a great deal that can be achieved by doing that. From the little we saw of the programs, they have been remarkably successful. But, sadly, the trade in women and in drugs continues and a great deal more needs to be done.

My final observation is with respect to the Australia-Thai Chamber of Commerce in Bangkok itself. A great deal can be done for the relationship between Australia and other countries through those who are resident Australians. I commend the members of that chamber, although their politics and their emphasis may not always be the same as Australia's, in that they sometimes have localised concerns. We were very fortunate on this visit—one of several visits I have had—to have met members of that chamber. They do a great job, and I believe that the government needs to work very closely with them, as they do with the NGOs, for we have a very worthwhile extension of Australia in those who are Australians and who see things through our eyes in the work they do in countries such as Thailand. I commend this report to the parliament. It has a great deal within it which should be accepted by the federal government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to rise today in support of the comments of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and, of course, in support of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade report on Australia's relations with Thailand. I also commend committee members who have spoken earlier today on the two JFADT reports here, particularly on the one in relation to Burma. These reports all really show the importance of parliamentary committees such as the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.
