PARA.TAB: Whilst I only joined this committee in June of this year, it has been an important time for any committee. The quality of these reports is certainly in tune with the high quality of reports that come out of this parliament all the time from the committees. That does great credit to the staff of the various committees in this parliament, and I commend them particularly for the quality of the reports before us at the moment.

Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, you actually led a parliamentary delegation to Thailand and Singapore just recently, and I had the pleasure of joining you on that occasion. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) was your deputy, and Senator Watson and the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) were part of that delegation as well. It fell out very nicely that we had the opportunity to visit Thailand and that I have the opportunity to say a few words about this report today. The foreword to the report on Australia's relations with Thailand says:

SPEECH.PARA: 8.As was stated in the Foreword to the report on relations with Indonesia, the Committee does not believe a credible report can be produced on a country unless a body of its members have seen something of that nation and its people. The opportunity to survey Australian development assistance projects and listen to Thailand's politicians, business people and public servants was of central importance to this inquiry.

Members of this committee have obviously visited the country over the last couple of years, as the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) has mentioned. Having recently visited Thailand, we can add to those comments.

PARA.TAB: What we say here is that the relationship with neighbours like Thailand is very important, and I think it can only be promoted by such bilateral visits. We had the opportunity to meet fellow members of parliament and the business community in Thailand and to look at some of Australia's aid programs in that area. We certainly had the opportunity to visit a camp on the Myanmar border, which I mentioned in the main chamber when the report on Burma was actually tabled. We went to a camp there that had some 6,000 people, Karen people, who were refugees. In that part of the world they are known as misplaced people, I think, for various reasons. That was an eye-opener to us, I believe, in seeing the problems that Thailand faces in that relationship with Burma and how those people are accommodated.

This all develops the problems that we need to address when we are talking about our neighbours like Thailand. I have got to admit that I was particularly pleased at the warmth with which we were greeted on that occasion. Once again it adds to the relationship that we have with Asia, and it is very important that we had the opportunity to go through and see all those things on that occasion.

We might look at the aid projects there. In particular, we had the opportunity to look at some of the health aid assistance that we are giving to Thailand, particularly when it comes to the HIV-AIDS problem, which is a very significant problem in Thailand, as acknowledged by the government. If Australia's aid can help in any way in addressing those sorts of health problems, it is certainly money well spent. I would like to commend the people that we saw on that occasion, who were working so closely in assisting those people with something that is certainly a big problem. In the briefing notes prepared for us, that was highlighted as one of the biggest issues there.

I commend this report and its recommendations. It does acknowledge the difficulties there and recommends a continuation of that support, but I think that what is probably often overlooked is the opportunities for Australian business in dealing with Thailand. That is a two-way go as well. It may be recalled that we visited the lignite mine project at Mae Moh with the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand. There was actually an Australian there—the project manager, Max Brown, who has been there for something like 12 years. He has done a tremendous job in promoting Australia. This is part of our aid program but there are mutual benefits in this particular aid program. I suggest that Australian business is benefiting very much from the relationship we have there through Australian assistance and the mutual benefits that come back through Australian trade.

When it comes to the mining industry, Australians have a lot to offer, as many members in this place know. I notice the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) here; he knows about the interest in the coal industry from his own electorate as well. The opportunities that have been made available there for Australian business to play an important role in assisting Thailand need to be highlighted, and the work of someone like Max Brown is particularly important because it really puts Australia on the world stage. I will read from the report that Max gave us:

SPEECH.PARA: The biggest business directed towards the Australian industry is in the materials handling system, where the Australian mining industry suppliers are competing with mainly European companies for the contract to supply, install and commission. Australian finance organisations have been involved, such as EFIC, to provide the Australian suppliers with competitive finance packages.

That is something that I think we often forget about the competition that is going on there. Max Brown told us how he competes almost on a daily basis with, for instance, the Germans, who would love to be in there doing as a good job as the Australians, but they obviously cannot be as effective as the Australians. The overall management there, of course, is run very well by the Thais. They address a lot of the environmental issues. We are getting more environmentally conscious in Australia with our mines as well as with redeveloping the sites afterwards. We had the opportunity to see the good work that was actually going on there in redeveloping those sites and being environmentally conscious. I think that was particularly important.

PARA.TAB: I briefly turn to another area which is of significance to the relationship between Australia and Thailand. That is the Thai-Burma railway, which is so infamously known, when we think about people like Weary Dunlop in particular, and the Hellfire Pass memorial project which was announced in the last budget. I believe that the longstanding good relations we have had with Thailand come through in the support that they are giving to the recognition of Australians who have gone before us in that particular conflict. It was obviously a horrible situation. I am sure you would recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, when we had the opportunity to wander down Hellfire Pass, the stress and strain of just walking down there and climbing out of the place. I know you were not well on that occasion, with a virus, but I would suggest that a lot of the POWs who were there would have been suffering much worse health problems than we would have on that occasion. It was certainly an eye-opener to me to actually walk down there and to look at the memorial to Weary Dunlop.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very moving to walk down that line.

—The honourable member for Cowper rightly interjects that it is very moving. I think you can probably hear the voices somewhere there. It was important for our delegation to be able to pay tribute to those who have gone before us, and to have a hand in maintaining the cooperation and the goodwill between our two nations. I pay tribute to the Thai government for the courtesy that they paid us right throughout our visit to Thailand. I am not sure we will get a chance to speak on another occasion when our report is actually tabled, but I want to put that on record today. Coming back to the tragedy on the Burma railway, I believe that the goodwill that the Thai government has shown to us in assisting us in the memorial there is extremely important to help foster the relationship.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to take too much time in the Committee, but I put on record my thanks to the Thai government. I think the right honourable member for New England talked about the very strong cultural differences between Thai people and us. That is true not only for that country but for many other countries. It is something that we need to accommodate and work through as we deal with developing good relationships in Asia. We are very well respected, I believe, as a country in Thailand and I think that we cannot but help to maintain and build on those relations by having our committees, such as the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, look at that relationship, foster that relationship and highlight any difficulties that we see, because that only helps.

We should be careful in how we deal with those things, because dealing with another country is very sensitive and it is not for us to tell another country how to run its show. But if we see things where we can offer assistance in some way, particularly in relation to that health area where Australia has expertise, and on the education side as well, then there are great opportunities for us to continue to maintain and foster those good relationships.

Many Thai people take the opportunity to educate their children in Australia for obvious reasons. It is a preferred place for many of them. It was surprising the number of people that we spoke to on that occasion who were educated in Australia. They have benefited greatly from that in making friends with Australia and, of course, learning our language rather than our learning their language. The language barrier that the right honourable member for New England highlighted before is certainly a problem for us. It is something that Australia needs to be very conscious of and I think that it is one language that we should be promoting in our schools if we are to continue to foster those relationships. All those areas are ones that we should promote, and I believe that a lot of the recommendations in the report do pick up on those.

The question of labour relations is something that is always very sensitive for members, certainly from my side of the House. With building sites in Thailand, for instance, one would suggest that there are always ways to improve. We can offer some advice and some expertise in developing a lot of those things, but on a two-way basis where we are careful how we develop those good relationships.

I am very pleased to have the opportunity to support this report. Again, I commend the staff of the committee for the three reports that have been tabled today. They are obviously of the very high quality that we maintain in this place. I commend the report to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Nehl) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 25 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What development cooperation commitments has the Australian Government entered into with other countries for each financial year from 1996-97 to and including 2000-2001.

(2) With respect to each commitment referred to in part (1), (a) which country will receive assistance, (b) what sum is involved, (c) what project will be undertaken and (d) what is the nature of the agreement through which assistance was committed.
(3) What contractual arrangements has the Australian Government entered into under the Development Import Finance Facility for each financial year from 1996-97 to and including 2000-2001.
(4) What total sum has been contracted for each year referred to in part (3).
(5) With respect to each contract referred to in part (3), (a) who is the contracting party, (b) what project is involved and (c) what is the value of the project.

(6) What percentage of projected total (a) development cooperation funds and (b) expenditure on the Development Import Finance Facility has been committed to date for each financial year from 1996-97 to and including 2000-2001.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The aggregated total forward development cooperation commitments, determined as at 30 September 1995, for each of the financial years 1996/97 to 2000/01 are listed in Attachment I. These are recorded against AusAID's appropriation structure; country programs, global programs and corporate services.

It is important to note that Australia's commitment to food aid is a special case. A liability has been incurred through our commitment to the Food Aid Convention of 300,000 tonnes of wheat or wheat equivalent per annum for the period 1995/96 to 1997/98. There is no specific allocation for food aid as such. Rather, our Food Aid Commitment is met through country appropriations, emergency and refugee appropriations, as well as through the World Food Program.

The commitments have been recorded in accordance with the accounting definitions specified by the Department of Finance in its guidelines to Commonwealth agencies for the preparation of annual Financial Statements tabled in Parliament. Obligations are recorded as liabilities, commitments and agreements equally proportionately unperformed (AEPUs). These definitions are explained at Attachment II.

Using these definitions, the levels of forward commitment as at 30 September 1995 are as follows: 1996/97—$1,055 million; 1997/98—$908 million; 1998/99—$678 million; 1999/2000—$595 million; 2000/01—$481 million.

There are other programs/activities which are not covered by these definitions and therefore not recorded for the purpose of the Financial Statements, but which also place a high degree of obligation on Australia for moral or other reasons. While there are strong expectations that such funding will continue, these activities have not been included as development cooperation commitments for these Questions on Notice.

These other obligations include core contributions to United Nations development organisations (eg. UNICEF, United Nations Development Fund, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees). The contributions are voluntary and not covered by legislation as in the case of multilateral development banks, nor are they covered by the `assessed' formulae used for other UN bodies. There is, however, a strong expectation internationally and domestically that Australia's contributions to these organisations will continue, reflecting Australia's role as a good international citizen and the principle of burden-sharing with other donors.

The category also covers: allocations to meet commitments where the Government has pledged support for specific programs (eg. Prime Ministerial multiyear pledges for development cooperation programs in Vietnam and Cambodia); provision for refugee and emergency relief; funding for Development Import Finance Facility projects where activities have been agreed between Australia and recipient governments; funding for the AusAID/Non-government Organisation Cooperation Program; funding for volunteer programs; and support for regional organisations such as the South Pacific Forum Secretariat. There is also an expectation of maintenance of support for country programs in key regions such as the South Pacific.
For 1996/97, the total value of these `strong expectations' is estimated to be $363 million.

(2) A detailed supplementary paper of 127 pages, which outlines all forward commitments, disaggregated by country program, global program and corporate services; and further, by activity, value and nature of commitment has been provided to the Honourable Member. Each commitment type is reported on separate schedules.

(3) Under the Development Import Finance Facility a contractual commitment occurs when the implementing contractor receives a formal offer to undertake the project. At 30 September 1995 no contractual arrangements were in place under the Development Import Finance Facility for project funding in 1996/97 and beyond.

There is, however, a high degree of obligation on the Australian Government because (i) a pipeline of projects has been agreed bilaterally at officials level with China, Indonesia, Nepal, India, the Philippines and Vietnam; and (ii) on this basis commercial contract negotiations between contractors and recipient governments have commenced. Details of individual contractors, prior to the award of contracts, are commercial-in-confidence.
(4) There were no contractual arrangements in place under the Development Import Finance Facility for the period 1996/97 to 2000/01 as at 30 September 1995.
There are, however, expectations based on requests on hand to a total value of $267.9 million, of which it is anticipated that some $60 million

ANSWER.PARA: will be funded during the remainder of the 1995/96 financial year and the balance funded in out years. Funding is provided as contracts are signed in any year up to the total annual allocation for the Development Import Finance Facility program. There are expectations of funding from the countries concerned and Australian contractors for these projects and, on that basis, contract negotiations have commenced. It should be noted that not all the identified projects will necessarily proceed to formal offer by AusAID. The latter is contingent upon satisfactory appraisal by AusAID on developmental grounds, including an assessment against OECD criteria for mixed credits and the satisfactory conclusion to negotiations between the Australian supplier and the buyer in the recipient country. Attachment III provides the list of Development Import Finance Facility projects agreed with recipient governments.

PARA.TAB: (1) Introduction

The definitions covering financial commitments are those applicable to reporting requirements for the annual Financial Statements to Parliament. The listed categories; Commitments, Agreements Equally Proportionately Unperformed (AEPUs) and liabilities are mutually exclusive and are recorded separately.

These categories of commitments are reported separately in a Supplementary Paper, of 127 pages in length, which has been provided to the Office of the Honourable Senator. These provide a detailed outline of all forward commitments, disaggregated by country programs, global programs and corporate services as per AusAID's program structure; and further, by activity, value and nature of commitment.
(2) Commitments
There are two types of commitment recorded.
In Schedule A of the Supplementary Paper commitments are recorded where:

there is a firm intention to incur a future liability for goods or services which are yet to be provided. The commitment actually arises when a definite decision is made to incur the liability (eg. when FR 44A approval is given to a spending proposal); or

action has been taken to determine the actual amount of the commitment or a reliable estimate, and where the conditions to be satisfied under the obligation are clearly defined in a written agreement (eg written record of a High Level Consultation that specifies agreed individual activities including a firm estimate of cost). If the above requirements are not satisfied, then the intention to incur a future liability is considered too vague for there to be a commitment.
Schedule B records commitments covered by Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), which are firm agreements evidenced by a signed document that commits a firm dollar amount.
Where there are contracts arising from an MOU, these are recorded as an AEPU in Schedule C (see Section 3 below).
(3) Agreements Equally Proportionately Unperformed (AEPUs)

Once a signed contract exists, and before any work has been performed or payments have been made, a commitment becomes contracted expenditure unperformed. In accounting terms, contracted expenditure unperformed is known as an "agreement equally proportionately unperformed" or an "AEPU".

An AEPU arises at any point in an agreement and applies where contracted work remains to be performed and no payments have been made for the work yet to be done. (For example, where 60 per cent of a contracted activity has been completed and paid for, the remaining 40 per cent of work still constitutes an AEPU.) The same applies where goods are involved rather than services.
These agreements usually involve a legal commitment by AusAID. For example, where AusAID

ANSWER.PARA: has legally committed the Commonwealth to provide from future budgets from an existing contract. (Note: AEPUs are not restricted to contracted expenditure/receipts. However, most amounts included here are those that form part of an existing contract.)

PARA.TAB: AEPUs are recorded in Schedule C and show amounts which will be payable in each financial year until 2000/01.
(4) Liabilities
A liability arises where an intention to incur a future obligation becomes a present obligation.

There are few items that are reported as liabilities. These are the non-reciprocal treaty for budget support to Papua New Guinea, Nauru Settlement, payments under the Food Aid Convention, payments made to multilateral development banks from Special Appropriations and a range of AusAID employee entitlement provisions.
Liabilities are recorded on Page 1 of the Supplementary Paper.

(3) What sum is available at the date of answering this question for the acquisition of land for regional open space or environmental protection.
(4) Do any programs exist under which State and local governments may borrow Commonwealth funds for land acquisition for regional open space or environmental protection.
(5) Will the Government provide funds to other tiers of government to acquire land for environmental purposes; if so, what are the details.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Environment, Sport and Territories Portfolio provides funds for land acquisition for environmental protection under the following programs:

Daintree Rescue Program
World Heritage Property Management

Save the Bush (since 1990)—$450 000
Wet Tropics Management Authority (since 1990)—$3 185 292

Wet Tropics Management Authority (1995/6)—$1 904 893

(4) There are no such programs within my portfolio.

(5) The provision of funds for this purpose is a matter that will be dependent on a range of factors prevailing at the particular time. Such factors would include the environmental significance of the land in question, the availability of funds and competing priorities.
